the Rabbit coming to look for her, and she trembled till she shook the
house, quite forgetting that she was now about a thousand times as large
as the Rabbit, and had no reason to be afraid of it.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-118
text:
Presently the Rabbit came up to the door, and tried to open it; but, as
the door opened inwards, and Alice's elbow was pressed hard against it,
that attempt proved a failure. Alice heard it say to itself 'Then I'll
go round and get in at the window.'
caption:
Presently the Rabbit came up to the door, and tried to open it; but, as
the door opened inwards, and Alice's elbow was pressed hard against it,
that attempt proved a failure. Alice heard it say to itself 'Then I'll
go round and get in at the window.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-119
text:
'THAT you won't' thought Alice, and, after waiting till she fancied
she heard the Rabbit just under the window, she suddenly spread out her
hand, and made a snatch in the air. She did not get hold of anything,
but she heard a little shriek and a fall, and a crash of broken glass,
from which she concluded that it was just possible it had fallen into a
cucumber-frame, or something of the sort.
caption:
'THAT you won't' thought Alice, and, after waiting till she fancied
she heard the Rabbit just under the window, she suddenly spread out her
hand, and made a snatch in the air. She did not get hold of anything,
but she heard a little shriek and a fall, and a crash of broken glass,
from which she concluded that it was just possible it had fallen into a
cucumber-frame, or something of the sort.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-120
text:
Next came an angry voice–the Rabbit's–'Pat! Pat! Where are you?' And
then a voice she had never heard before, 'Sure then I'm here! Digging
for apples, yer honour!'
caption:
Next came an angry voice–the Rabbit's–'Pat! Pat! Where are you?' And
then a voice she had never heard before, 'Sure then I'm here! Digging
for apples, yer honour!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-121
text:
'Digging for apples, indeed!' said the Rabbit angrily. 'Here! Come and
help me out of THIS!' (Sounds of more broken glass.)
caption:
'Digging for apples, indeed!' said the Rabbit angrily. 'Here! Come and
help me out of THIS!' (Sounds of more broken glass.)

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-122
text: 'Now tell me, Pat, what's that in the window?'
caption: 'Now tell me, Pat, what's that in the window?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-123
text: 'Sure, it's an arm, yer honour!' (He pronounced it 'arrum.')
caption: 'Sure, it's an arm, yer honour!' (He pronounced it 'arrum.')

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-124
text:
'An arm, you goose! Who ever saw one that size? Why, it fills the whole
window!'
caption:
'An arm, you goose! Who ever saw one that size? Why, it fills the whole
window!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-125
text: 'Sure, it does, yer honour: but it's an arm for all that.'
caption: 'Sure, it does, yer honour: but it's an arm for all that.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-126
text: 'Well, it's got no business there, at any rate: go and take it away!'
caption: 'Well, it's got no business there, at any rate: go and take it away!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-127
text:
There was a long silence after this, and Alice could only hear whispers
now and then; such as, 'Sure, I don't like it, yer honour, at all, at
all!' 'Do as I tell you, you coward!' and at last she spread out her
hand again, and made another snatch in the air. This time there were
TWO little shrieks, and more sounds of broken glass. 'What a number of
cucumber-frames there must be!' thought Alice. 'I wonder what they'll do
next! As for pulling me out of the window, I only wish they COULD! I'm
sure I don't want to stay in here any longer!'
caption:
There was a long silence after this, and Alice could only hear whispers
now and then; such as, 'Sure, I don't like it, yer honour, at all, at
all!' 'Do as I tell you, you coward!' and at last she spread out her
hand again, and made another snatch in the air. This time there were
TWO little shrieks, and more sounds of broken glass. 'What a number of
cucumber-frames there must be!' thought Alice. 'I wonder what they'll do
next! As for pulling me out of the window, I only wish they COULD! I'm
sure I don't want to stay in here any longer!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-128
text:
She waited for some time without hearing anything more: at last came a
rumbling of little cartwheels, and the sound of a good many voices
all talking together: she made out the words: 'Where's the other
ladder?–Why, I hadn't to bring but one; Bill's got the other–Bill!
fetch it here, lad!–Here, put 'em up at this corner–No, tie 'em
together first–they don't reach half high enough yet–Oh! they'll
do well enough; don't be particular–Here, Bill! catch hold of this
rope–Will the roof bear?–Mind that loose slate–Oh, it's coming
down! Heads below!' (a loud crash)–'Now, who did that?–It was Bill, I
fancy–Who's to go down the chimney?–Nay, I shan't! YOU do it!–That I
won't, then!–Bill's to go down–Here, Bill! the master says you're to
go down the chimney!'
caption:
She waited for some time without hearing anything more: at last came a
rumbling of little cartwheels, and the sound of a good many voices
all talking together: she made out the words: 'Where's the other
ladder?–Why, I hadn't to bring but one; Bill's got the other–Bill!
fetch it here, lad!–Here, put 'em up at this corner–No, tie 'em
together first–they don't reach half high enough yet–Oh! they'll
do well enough; don't be particular–Here, Bill! catch hold of this
rope–Will the roof bear?–Mind that loose slate–Oh, it's coming
down! Heads below!' (a loud crash)–'Now, who did that?–It was Bill, I
fancy–Who's to go down the chimney?–Nay, I shan't! YOU do it!–That I
won't, then!–Bill's to go down–Here, Bill! the master says you're to
go down the chimney!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-129
text:
'Oh! So Bill's got to come down the chimney, has he?' said Alice to
herself. 'Shy, they seem to put everything upon Bill! I wouldn't be in
Bill's place for a good deal: this fireplace is narrow, to be sure; but
I THINK I can kick a little!'
caption:
'Oh! So Bill's got to come down the chimney, has he?' said Alice to
herself. 'Shy, they seem to put everything upon Bill! I wouldn't be in
Bill's place for a good deal: this fireplace is narrow, to be sure; but
I THINK I can kick a little!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-130
text:
She drew her foot as far down the chimney as she could, and waited
till she heard a little animal (she couldn't guess of what sort it was)
scratching and scrambling about in the chimney close above her: then,
saying to herself 'This is Bill,' she gave one sharp kick, and waited to
see what would happen next.
caption:
She drew her foot as far down the chimney as she could, and waited
till she heard a little animal (she couldn't guess of what sort it was)
scratching and scrambling about in the chimney close above her: then,
saying to herself 'This is Bill,' she gave one sharp kick, and waited to
see what would happen next.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-131
text:
The first thing she heard was a general chorus of 'There goes Bill!'
then the Rabbit's voice along–'Catch him, you by the hedge!' then
silence, and then another confusion of voices–'Hold up his head–Brandy
now–Don't choke him–How was it, old fellow? What happened to you? Tell
us all about it!'
caption:
The first thing she heard was a general chorus of 'There goes Bill!'
then the Rabbit's voice along–'Catch him, you by the hedge!' then
silence, and then another confusion of voices–'Hold up his head–Brandy
now–Don't choke him–How was it, old fellow? What happened to you? Tell
us all about it!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-132
text:
Last came a little feeble, squeaking voice, ('That's Bill,' thought
Alice,) 'Well, I hardly know–No more, thank ye; I'm better now–but I'm
a deal too flustered to tell you–all I know is, something comes at me
like a Jack-in-the-box, and up I goes like a sky-rocket!'
caption:
Last came a little feeble, squeaking voice, ('That's Bill,' thought
Alice,) 'Well, I hardly know–No more, thank ye; I'm better now–but I'm
a deal too flustered to tell you–all I know is, something comes at me
like a Jack-in-the-box, and up I goes like a sky-rocket!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-133
text: 'So you did, old fellow!' said the others.
caption: 'So you did, old fellow!' said the others.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-134
text:
'We must burn the house down!' said the Rabbit's voice; and Alice called
out as loud as she could, 'If you do. I'll set Dinah at you!'
caption:
'We must burn the house down!' said the Rabbit's voice; and Alice called
out as loud as she could, 'If you do. I'll set Dinah at you!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-135
text:
There was a dead silence instantly, and Alice thought to herself, 'I
wonder what they WILL do next! If they had any sense, they'd take the
roof off.' After a minute or two, they began moving about again, and
Alice heard the Rabbit say, 'A barrowful will do, to begin with.'
caption:
There was a dead silence instantly, and Alice thought to herself, 'I
wonder what they WILL do next! If they had any sense, they'd take the
roof off.' After a minute or two, they began moving about again, and
Alice heard the Rabbit say, 'A barrowful will do, to begin with.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-136
text:
'A barrowful of WHAT?' thought Alice; but she had not long to doubt,
for the next moment a shower of little pebbles came rattling in at the
window, and some of them hit her in the face. 'I'll put a stop to this,'
she said to herself, and shouted out, 'You'd better not do that again!'
which produced another dead silence.
caption:
'A barrowful of WHAT?' thought Alice; but she had not long to doubt,
for the next moment a shower of little pebbles came rattling in at the
window, and some of them hit her in the face. 'I'll put a stop to this,'
she said to herself, and shouted out, 'You'd better not do that again!'
which produced another dead silence.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-137
text:
Alice noticed with some surprise that the pebbles were all turning into
little cakes as they lay on the floor, and a bright idea came into her
head. 'If I eat one of these cakes,' she thought, 'it's sure to make
SOME change in my size; and as it can't possibly make me larger, it must
make me smaller, I suppose.'
caption:
Alice noticed with some surprise that the pebbles were all turning into
little cakes as they lay on the floor, and a bright idea came into her
head. 'If I eat one of these cakes,' she thought, 'it's sure to make
SOME change in my size; and as it can't possibly make me larger, it must
make me smaller, I suppose.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-138
text:
So she swallowed one of the cakes, and was delighted to find that she
began shrinking directly. As soon as she was small enough to get through
the door, she ran out of the house, and found quite a crowd of little
animals and birds waiting outside. The poor little Lizard, Bill, was
in the middle, being held up by two guinea-pigs, who were giving it
something out of a bottle. They all made a rush at Alice the moment she
appeared; but she ran off as hard as she could, and soon found herself
safe in a thick wood.
caption:
So she swallowed one of the cakes, and was delighted to find that she
began shrinking directly. As soon as she was small enough to get through
the door, she ran out of the house, and found quite a crowd of little
animals and birds waiting outside. The poor little Lizard, Bill, was
in the middle, being held up by two guinea-pigs, who were giving it
something out of a bottle. They all made a rush at Alice the moment she
appeared; but she ran off as hard as she could, and soon found herself
safe in a thick wood.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-139
text:
'The first thing I've got to do,' said Alice to herself, as she wandered
about in the wood, 'is to grow to my right size again; and the second
thing is to find my way into that lovely garden. I think that will be
the best plan.'
caption:
'The first thing I've got to do,' said Alice to herself, as she wandered
about in the wood, 'is to grow to my right size again; and the second
thing is to find my way into that lovely garden. I think that will be
the best plan.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-140
text:
It sounded an excellent plan, no doubt, and very neatly and simply
arranged; the only difficulty was, that she had not the smallest idea
how to set about it; and while she was peering about anxiously among
the trees, a little sharp bark just over her head made her look up in a
great hurry.
caption:
It sounded an excellent plan, no doubt, and very neatly and simply
arranged; the only difficulty was, that she had not the smallest idea
how to set about it; and while she was peering about anxiously among
the trees, a little sharp bark just over her head made her look up in a
great hurry.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-141
text:
An enormous puppy was looking down at her with large round eyes, and
feebly stretching out one paw, trying to touch her. 'Poor little thing!'
said Alice, in a coaxing tone, and she tried hard to whistle to it; but
she was terribly frightened all the time at the thought that it might be
hungry, in which case it would be very likely to eat her up in spite of
all her coaxing.
caption:
An enormous puppy was looking down at her with large round eyes, and
feebly stretching out one paw, trying to touch her. 'Poor little thing!'
said Alice, in a coaxing tone, and she tried hard to whistle to it; but
she was terribly frightened all the time at the thought that it might be
hungry, in which case it would be very likely to eat her up in spite of
all her coaxing.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-142
text:
Hardly knowing what she did, she picked up a little bit of stick, and
held it out to the puppy; whereupon the puppy jumped into the air off
all its feet at once, with a yelp of delight, and rushed at the stick,
and made believe to worry it; then Alice dodged behind a great thistle,
to keep herself from being run over; and the moment she appeared on the
other side, the puppy made another rush at the stick, and tumbled head
over heels in its hurry to get hold of it; then Alice, thinking it was
very like having a game of play with a cart-horse, and expecting every
moment to be trampled under its feet, ran round the thistle again; then
the puppy began a series of short charges at the stick, running a very
little way forwards each time and a long way back, and barking hoarsely
all the while, till at last it sat down a good way off, panting, with
its tongue hanging out of its mouth, and its great eyes half shut.
caption:
Hardly knowing what she did, she picked up a little bit of stick, and
held it out to the puppy; whereupon the puppy jumped into the air off
all its feet at once, with a yelp of delight, and rushed at the stick,
and made believe to worry it; then Alice dodged behind a great thistle,
to keep herself from being run over; and the moment she appeared on the
other side, the puppy made another rush at the stick, and tumbled head
over heels in its hurry to get hold of it; then Alice, thinking it was
very like having a game of play with a cart-horse, and expecting every
moment to be trampled under its feet, ran round the thistle again; then
the puppy began a series of short charges at the stick, running a very
little way forwards each time and a long way back, and barking hoarsely
all the while, till at last it sat down a good way off, panting, with
its tongue hanging out of its mouth, and its great eyes half shut.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-143
text:
This seemed to Alice a good opportunity for making her escape; so she
set off at once, and ran till she was quite tired and out of breath, and
till the puppy's bark sounded quite faint in the distance.
caption:
This seemed to Alice a good opportunity for making her escape; so she
set off at once, and ran till she was quite tired and out of breath, and
till the puppy's bark sounded quite faint in the distance.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-144
text:
'And yet what a dear little puppy it was!' said Alice, as she leant
against a buttercup to rest herself, and fanned herself with one of the
leaves: 'I should have liked teaching it tricks very much, if–if I'd
only been the right size to do it! Oh dear! I'd nearly forgotten that
I've got to grow up again! Let me see–how IS it to be managed? I
suppose I ought to eat or drink something or other; but the great
question is, what?'
caption:
'And yet what a dear little puppy it was!' said Alice, as she leant
against a buttercup to rest herself, and fanned herself with one of the
leaves: 'I should have liked teaching it tricks very much, if–if I'd
only been the right size to do it! Oh dear! I'd nearly forgotten that
I've got to grow up again! Let me see–how IS it to be managed? I
suppose I ought to eat or drink something or other; but the great
question is, what?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-145
text:
The great question certainly was, what? Alice looked all round her at
the flowers and the blades of grass, but she did not see anything that
looked like the right thing to eat or drink under the circumstances.
There was a large mushroom growing near her, about the same height as
herself; and when she had looked under it, and on both sides of it, and
behind it, it occurred to her that she might as well look and see what
was on the top of it.
caption:
The great question certainly was, what? Alice looked all round her at
the flowers and the blades of grass, but she did not see anything that
looked like the right thing to eat or drink under the circumstances.
There was a large mushroom growing near her, about the same height as
herself; and when she had looked under it, and on both sides of it, and
behind it, it occurred to her that she might as well look and see what
was on the top of it.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-146
text:
She stretched herself up on tiptoe, and peeped over the edge of the
mushroom, and her eyes immediately met those of a large caterpillar,
that was sitting on the top with its arms folded, quietly smoking a long
hookah, and taking not the smallest notice of her or of anything else.
caption:
She stretched herself up on tiptoe, and peeped over the edge of the
mushroom, and her eyes immediately met those of a large caterpillar,
that was sitting on the top with its arms folded, quietly smoking a long
hookah, and taking not the smallest notice of her or of anything else.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-147
text: CHAPTER V. Advice from a Caterpillar
caption: CHAPTER V. Advice from a Caterpillar

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-148
text:
The Caterpillar and Alice looked at each other for some time in silence:
at last the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth, and addressed
her in a languid, sleepy voice.
caption:
The Caterpillar and Alice looked at each other for some time in silence:
at last the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth, and addressed
her in a languid, sleepy voice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-149
text: 'Who are YOU?' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'Who are YOU?' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-150
text:
This was not an encouraging opening for a conversation. Alice replied,
rather shyly, 'I–I hardly know, sir, just at present–at least I know
who I WAS when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been
changed several times since then.'
caption:
This was not an encouraging opening for a conversation. Alice replied,
rather shyly, 'I–I hardly know, sir, just at present–at least I know
who I WAS when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been
changed several times since then.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-151
text:
'What do you mean by that?' said the Caterpillar sternly. 'Explain
yourself!'
caption:
'What do you mean by that?' said the Caterpillar sternly. 'Explain
yourself!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-152
text:
'I can't explain MYSELF, I'm afraid, sir' said Alice, 'because I'm not
myself, you see.'
caption:
'I can't explain MYSELF, I'm afraid, sir' said Alice, 'because I'm not
myself, you see.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-153
text: 'I don't see,' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'I don't see,' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-154
text:
'I'm afraid I can't put it more clearly,' Alice replied very politely,
'for I can't understand it myself to begin with; and being so many
different sizes in a day is very confusing.'
caption:
'I'm afraid I can't put it more clearly,' Alice replied very politely,
'for I can't understand it myself to begin with; and being so many
different sizes in a day is very confusing.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-155
text: 'It isn't,' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'It isn't,' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-156
text:
'Well, perhaps you haven't found it so yet,' said Alice; 'but when you
have to turn into a chrysalis–you will some day, you know–and then
after that into a butterfly, I should think you'll feel it a little
queer, won't you?'
caption:
'Well, perhaps you haven't found it so yet,' said Alice; 'but when you
have to turn into a chrysalis–you will some day, you know–and then
after that into a butterfly, I should think you'll feel it a little
queer, won't you?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-157
text: 'Not a bit,' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'Not a bit,' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-158
text:
'Well, perhaps your feelings may be different,' said Alice; 'all I know
is, it would feel very queer to ME.'
caption:
'Well, perhaps your feelings may be different,' said Alice; 'all I know
is, it would feel very queer to ME.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-159
text: 'You!' said the Caterpillar contemptuously. 'Who are YOU?'
caption: 'You!' said the Caterpillar contemptuously. 'Who are YOU?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-160
text:
Which brought them back again to the beginning of the conversation.
Alice felt a little irritated at the Caterpillar's making such VERY
short remarks, and she drew herself up and said, very gravely, 'I think,
you ought to tell me who YOU are, first.'
caption:
Which brought them back again to the beginning of the conversation.
Alice felt a little irritated at the Caterpillar's making such VERY
short remarks, and she drew herself up and said, very gravely, 'I think,
you ought to tell me who YOU are, first.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-161
text: 'Why?' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'Why?' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-162
text:
Here was another puzzling question; and as Alice could not think of any
good reason, and as the Caterpillar seemed to be in a VERY unpleasant
state of mind, she turned away.
caption:
Here was another puzzling question; and as Alice could not think of any
good reason, and as the Caterpillar seemed to be in a VERY unpleasant
state of mind, she turned away.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-163
text:
'Come back!' the Caterpillar called after her. 'I've something important
to say!'
caption:
'Come back!' the Caterpillar called after her. 'I've something important
to say!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-164
text: This sounded promising, certainly: Alice turned and came back again.
caption: This sounded promising, certainly: Alice turned and came back again.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-165
text: 'Keep your temper,' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'Keep your temper,' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-166
text:
'Is that all?' said Alice, swallowing down her anger as well as she
could.
caption:
'Is that all?' said Alice, swallowing down her anger as well as she
could.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-167
text: 'No,' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'No,' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-168
text:
Alice thought she might as well wait, as she had nothing else to do, and
perhaps after all it might tell her something worth hearing. For some
minutes it puffed away without speaking, but at last it unfolded its
arms, took the hookah out of its mouth again, and said, 'So you think
you're changed, do you?'
caption:
Alice thought she might as well wait, as she had nothing else to do, and
perhaps after all it might tell her something worth hearing. For some
minutes it puffed away without speaking, but at last it unfolded its
arms, took the hookah out of its mouth again, and said, 'So you think
you're changed, do you?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-169
text:
'I'm afraid I am, sir,' said Alice; 'I can't remember things as I
used–and I don't keep the same size for ten minutes together!'
caption:
'I'm afraid I am, sir,' said Alice; 'I can't remember things as I
used–and I don't keep the same size for ten minutes together!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-170
text: 'Can't remember WHAT things?' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'Can't remember WHAT things?' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-171
text:
'Well, I've tried to say "HOW DOTH THE LITTLE BUSY BEE," but it all came
different!' Alice replied in a very melancholy voice.
caption:
'Well, I've tried to say "HOW DOTH THE LITTLE BUSY BEE," but it all came
different!' Alice replied in a very melancholy voice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-172
text: 'Repeat, "YOU ARE OLD, FATHER WILLIAM,"' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'Repeat, "YOU ARE OLD, FATHER WILLIAM,"' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-173
text: Alice folded her hands, and began:–
caption: Alice folded her hands, and began:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-174
text:
'You are old, Father William,' the young man said,
    'And your hair has become very white;
   And yet you incessantly stand on your head–
    Do you think, at your age, it is right?'
caption:
'You are old, Father William,' the young man said,
    'And your hair has become very white;
   And yet you incessantly stand on your head–
    Do you think, at your age, it is right?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-175
text:
'In my youth,' Father William replied to his son,
    'I feared it might injure the brain;
   But, now that I'm perfectly sure I have none,
    Why, I do it again and again.'
caption:
'In my youth,' Father William replied to his son,
    'I feared it might injure the brain;
   But, now that I'm perfectly sure I have none,
    Why, I do it again and again.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-176
text:
'You are old,' said the youth, 'as I mentioned before,
    And have grown most uncommonly fat;
   Yet you turned a back-somersault in at the door–
    Pray, what is the reason of that?'
caption:
'You are old,' said the youth, 'as I mentioned before,
    And have grown most uncommonly fat;
   Yet you turned a back-somersault in at the door–
    Pray, what is the reason of that?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-177
text:
'In my youth,' said the sage, as he shook his grey locks,
    'I kept all my limbs very supple
   By the use of this ointment–one shilling the box–
    Allow me to sell you a couple?'
caption:
'In my youth,' said the sage, as he shook his grey locks,
    'I kept all my limbs very supple
   By the use of this ointment–one shilling the box–
    Allow me to sell you a couple?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-178
text:
'You are old,' said the youth, 'and your jaws are too weak
    For anything tougher than suet;
   Yet you finished the goose, with the bones and the beak–
    Pray how did you manage to do it?'
caption:
'You are old,' said the youth, 'and your jaws are too weak
    For anything tougher than suet;
   Yet you finished the goose, with the bones and the beak–
    Pray how did you manage to do it?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-179
text:
'In my youth,' said his father, 'I took to the law,
    And argued each case with my wife;
   And the muscular strength, which it gave to my jaw,
    Has lasted the rest of my life.'
caption:
'In my youth,' said his father, 'I took to the law,
    And argued each case with my wife;
   And the muscular strength, which it gave to my jaw,
    Has lasted the rest of my life.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-180
text:
'You are old,' said the youth, 'one would hardly suppose
    That your eye was as steady as ever;
   Yet you balanced an eel on the end of your nose–
    What made you so awfully clever?'
caption:
'You are old,' said the youth, 'one would hardly suppose
    That your eye was as steady as ever;
   Yet you balanced an eel on the end of your nose–
    What made you so awfully clever?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-181
text:
'I have answered three questions, and that is enough,'
    Said his father; 'don't give yourself airs!
   Do you think I can listen all day to such stuff?
    Be off, or I'll kick you down stairs!'
caption:
'I have answered three questions, and that is enough,'
    Said his father; 'don't give yourself airs!
   Do you think I can listen all day to such stuff?
    Be off, or I'll kick you down stairs!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-182
text: 'That is not said right,' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'That is not said right,' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-183
text:
'Not QUITE right, I'm afraid,' said Alice, timidly; 'some of the words
have got altered.'
caption:
'Not QUITE right, I'm afraid,' said Alice, timidly; 'some of the words
have got altered.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-184
text:
'It is wrong from beginning to end,' said the Caterpillar decidedly, and
there was silence for some minutes.
caption:
'It is wrong from beginning to end,' said the Caterpillar decidedly, and
there was silence for some minutes.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-185
text: The Caterpillar was the first to speak.
caption: The Caterpillar was the first to speak.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-186
text: 'What size do you want to be?' it asked.
caption: 'What size do you want to be?' it asked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-187
text:
'Oh, I'm not particular as to size,' Alice hastily replied; 'only one
doesn't like changing so often, you know.'
caption:
'Oh, I'm not particular as to size,' Alice hastily replied; 'only one
doesn't like changing so often, you know.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-188
text: 'I DON'T know,' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'I DON'T know,' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-189
text:
Alice said nothing: she had never been so much contradicted in her life
before, and she felt that she was losing her temper.
caption:
Alice said nothing: she had never been so much contradicted in her life
before, and she felt that she was losing her temper.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-190
text: 'Are you content now?' said the Caterpillar.
caption: 'Are you content now?' said the Caterpillar.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-191
text:
'Well, I should like to be a LITTLE larger, sir, if you wouldn't mind,'
said Alice: 'three inches is such a wretched height to be.'
caption:
'Well, I should like to be a LITTLE larger, sir, if you wouldn't mind,'
said Alice: 'three inches is such a wretched height to be.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-192
text:
'It is a very good height indeed!' said the Caterpillar angrily, rearing
itself upright as it spoke (it was exactly three inches high).
caption:
'It is a very good height indeed!' said the Caterpillar angrily, rearing
itself upright as it spoke (it was exactly three inches high).

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-193
text:
'But I'm not used to it!' pleaded poor Alice in a piteous tone. And
she thought of herself, 'I wish the creatures wouldn't be so easily
offended!'
caption:
'But I'm not used to it!' pleaded poor Alice in a piteous tone. And
she thought of herself, 'I wish the creatures wouldn't be so easily
offended!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-194
text:
'You'll get used to it in time,' said the Caterpillar; and it put the
hookah into its mouth and began smoking again.
caption:
'You'll get used to it in time,' said the Caterpillar; and it put the
hookah into its mouth and began smoking again.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-195
text:
This time Alice waited patiently until it chose to speak again. In
a minute or two the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth
and yawned once or twice, and shook itself. Then it got down off the
mushroom, and crawled away in the grass, merely remarking as it went,
'One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you
grow shorter.'
caption:
This time Alice waited patiently until it chose to speak again. In
a minute or two the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth
and yawned once or twice, and shook itself. Then it got down off the
mushroom, and crawled away in the grass, merely remarking as it went,
'One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you
grow shorter.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-196
text: 'One side of WHAT? The other side of WHAT?' thought Alice to herself.
caption: 'One side of WHAT? The other side of WHAT?' thought Alice to herself.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-197
text:
'Of the mushroom,' said the Caterpillar, just as if she had asked it
aloud; and in another moment it was out of sight.
caption:
'Of the mushroom,' said the Caterpillar, just as if she had asked it
aloud; and in another moment it was out of sight.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-198
text:
Alice remained looking thoughtfully at the mushroom for a minute, trying
to make out which were the two sides of it; and as it was perfectly
round, she found this a very difficult question. However, at last she
stretched her arms round it as far as they would go, and broke off a bit
of the edge with each hand.
caption:
Alice remained looking thoughtfully at the mushroom for a minute, trying
to make out which were the two sides of it; and as it was perfectly
round, she found this a very difficult question. However, at last she
stretched her arms round it as far as they would go, and broke off a bit
of the edge with each hand.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-199
text:
'And now which is which?' she said to herself, and nibbled a little of
the right-hand bit to try the effect: the next moment she felt a violent
blow underneath her chin: it had struck her foot!
caption:
'And now which is which?' she said to herself, and nibbled a little of
the right-hand bit to try the effect: the next moment she felt a violent
blow underneath her chin: it had struck her foot!

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-200
text:
She was a good deal frightened by this very sudden change, but she felt
that there was no time to be lost, as she was shrinking rapidly; so she
set to work at once to eat some of the other bit. Her chin was pressed
so closely against her foot, that there was hardly room to open her
mouth; but she did it at last, and managed to swallow a morsel of the
lefthand bit.
caption:
She was a good deal frightened by this very sudden change, but she felt
that there was no time to be lost, as she was shrinking rapidly; so she
set to work at once to eat some of the other bit. Her chin was pressed
so closely against her foot, that there was hardly room to open her
mouth; but she did it at last, and managed to swallow a morsel of the
lefthand bit.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-202
text:
'Come, my head's free at last!' said Alice in a tone of delight, which
changed into alarm in another moment, when she found that her shoulders
were nowhere to be found: all she could see, when she looked down, was
an immense length of neck, which seemed to rise like a stalk out of a
sea of green leaves that lay far below her.
caption:
'Come, my head's free at last!' said Alice in a tone of delight, which
changed into alarm in another moment, when she found that her shoulders
were nowhere to be found: all she could see, when she looked down, was
an immense length of neck, which seemed to rise like a stalk out of a
sea of green leaves that lay far below her.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-203
text:
'What CAN all that green stuff be?' said Alice. 'And where HAVE my
shoulders got to? And oh, my poor hands, how is it I can't see you?'
She was moving them about as she spoke, but no result seemed to follow,
except a little shaking among the distant green leaves.
caption:
'What CAN all that green stuff be?' said Alice. 'And where HAVE my
shoulders got to? And oh, my poor hands, how is it I can't see you?'
She was moving them about as she spoke, but no result seemed to follow,
except a little shaking among the distant green leaves.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-204
text:
As there seemed to be no chance of getting her hands up to her head, she
tried to get her head down to them, and was delighted to find that her
neck would bend about easily in any direction, like a serpent. She had
just succeeded in curving it down into a graceful zigzag, and was going
to dive in among the leaves, which she found to be nothing but the tops
of the trees under which she had been wandering, when a sharp hiss made
her draw back in a hurry: a large pigeon had flown into her face, and
was beating her violently with its wings.
caption:
As there seemed to be no chance of getting her hands up to her head, she
tried to get her head down to them, and was delighted to find that her
neck would bend about easily in any direction, like a serpent. She had
just succeeded in curving it down into a graceful zigzag, and was going
to dive in among the leaves, which she found to be nothing but the tops
of the trees under which she had been wandering, when a sharp hiss made
her draw back in a hurry: a large pigeon had flown into her face, and
was beating her violently with its wings.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-205
text: 'Serpent!' screamed the Pigeon.
caption: 'Serpent!' screamed the Pigeon.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-206
text: 'I'm NOT a serpent!' said Alice indignantly. 'Let me alone!'
caption: 'I'm NOT a serpent!' said Alice indignantly. 'Let me alone!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-207
text:
'Serpent, I say again!' repeated the Pigeon, but in a more subdued tone,
and added with a kind of sob, 'I've tried every way, and nothing seems
to suit them!'
caption:
'Serpent, I say again!' repeated the Pigeon, but in a more subdued tone,
and added with a kind of sob, 'I've tried every way, and nothing seems
to suit them!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-208
text: 'I haven't the least idea what you're talking about,' said Alice.
caption: 'I haven't the least idea what you're talking about,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-209
text:
'I've tried the roots of trees, and I've tried banks, and I've tried
hedges,' the Pigeon went on, without attending to her; 'but those
serpents! There's no pleasing them!'
caption:
'I've tried the roots of trees, and I've tried banks, and I've tried
hedges,' the Pigeon went on, without attending to her; 'but those
serpents! There's no pleasing them!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-210
text:
Alice was more and more puzzled, but she thought there was no use in
saying anything more till the Pigeon had finished.
caption:
Alice was more and more puzzled, but she thought there was no use in
saying anything more till the Pigeon had finished.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-211
Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-212
text:
'I'm very sorry you've been annoyed,' said Alice, who was beginning to
see its meaning.
caption:
'I'm very sorry you've been annoyed,' said Alice, who was beginning to
see its meaning.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-213
text:
'And just as I'd taken the highest tree in the wood,' continued the
Pigeon, raising its voice to a shriek, 'and just as I was thinking I
should be free of them at last, they must needs come wriggling down from
the sky! Ugh, Serpent!'
caption:
'And just as I'd taken the highest tree in the wood,' continued the
Pigeon, raising its voice to a shriek, 'and just as I was thinking I
should be free of them at last, they must needs come wriggling down from
the sky! Ugh, Serpent!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-214
text: 'But I'm NOT a serpent, I tell you!' said Alice. 'I'm a–I'm a–'
caption: 'But I'm NOT a serpent, I tell you!' said Alice. 'I'm a–I'm a–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-215
text:
'Well! WHAT are you?' said the Pigeon. 'I can see you're trying to
invent something!'
caption:
'Well! WHAT are you?' said the Pigeon. 'I can see you're trying to
invent something!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-216
text:
'I–I'm a little girl,' said Alice, rather doubtfully, as she remembered
the number of changes she had gone through that day.
caption:
'I–I'm a little girl,' said Alice, rather doubtfully, as she remembered
the number of changes she had gone through that day.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-217
text:
'A likely story indeed!' said the Pigeon in a tone of the deepest
contempt. 'I've seen a good many little girls in my time, but never ONE
with such a neck as that! No, no! You're a serpent; and there's no use
denying it. I suppose you'll be telling me next that you never tasted an
egg!'
caption:
'A likely story indeed!' said the Pigeon in a tone of the deepest
contempt. 'I've seen a good many little girls in my time, but never ONE
with such a neck as that! No, no! You're a serpent; and there's no use
denying it. I suppose you'll be telling me next that you never tasted an
egg!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-218
text:
'I HAVE tasted eggs, certainly,' said Alice, who was a very truthful
child; 'but little girls eat eggs quite as much as serpents do, you
know.'
caption:
'I HAVE tasted eggs, certainly,' said Alice, who was a very truthful
child; 'but little girls eat eggs quite as much as serpents do, you
know.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-219
text:
'I don't believe it,' said the Pigeon; 'but if they do, why then they're
a kind of serpent, that's all I can say.'
caption:
'I don't believe it,' said the Pigeon; 'but if they do, why then they're
a kind of serpent, that's all I can say.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-220
text:
This was such a new idea to Alice, that she was quite silent for a
minute or two, which gave the Pigeon the opportunity of adding, 'You're
looking for eggs, I know THAT well enough; and what does it matter to me
whether you're a little girl or a serpent?'
caption:
This was such a new idea to Alice, that she was quite silent for a
minute or two, which gave the Pigeon the opportunity of adding, 'You're
looking for eggs, I know THAT well enough; and what does it matter to me
whether you're a little girl or a serpent?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-221
text:
'It matters a good deal to ME,' said Alice hastily; 'but I'm not looking
for eggs, as it happens; and if I was, I shouldn't want YOURS: I don't
like them raw.'
caption:
'It matters a good deal to ME,' said Alice hastily; 'but I'm not looking
for eggs, as it happens; and if I was, I shouldn't want YOURS: I don't
like them raw.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-222
text:
'Well, be off, then!' said the Pigeon in a sulky tone, as it settled
down again into its nest. Alice crouched down among the trees as well as
she could, for her neck kept getting entangled among the branches, and
every now and then she had to stop and untwist it. After a while she
remembered that she still held the pieces of mushroom in her hands, and
she set to work very carefully, nibbling first at one and then at the
other, and growing sometimes taller and sometimes shorter, until she had
succeeded in bringing herself down to her usual height.
caption:
'Well, be off, then!' said the Pigeon in a sulky tone, as it settled
down again into its nest. Alice crouched down among the trees as well as
she could, for her neck kept getting entangled among the branches, and
every now and then she had to stop and untwist it. After a while she
remembered that she still held the pieces of mushroom in her hands, and
she set to work very carefully, nibbling first at one and then at the
other, and growing sometimes taller and sometimes shorter, until she had
succeeded in bringing herself down to her usual height.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-223
text:
It was so long since she had been anything near the right size, that it
felt quite strange at first; but she got used to it in a few minutes,
and began talking to herself, as usual. 'Come, there's half my plan done
now! How puzzling all these changes are! I'm never sure what I'm going
to be, from one minute to another! However, I've got back to my right
size: the next thing is, to get into that beautiful garden–how IS that
to be done, I wonder?' As she said this, she came suddenly upon an open
place, with a little house in it about four feet high. 'Whoever lives
there,' thought Alice, 'it'll never do to come upon them THIS size: why,
I should frighten them out of their wits!' So she began nibbling at the
righthand bit again, and did not venture to go near the house till she
had brought herself down to nine inches high.
caption:
It was so long since she had been anything near the right size, that it
felt quite strange at first; but she got used to it in a few minutes,
and began talking to herself, as usual. 'Come, there's half my plan done
now! How puzzling all these changes are! I'm never sure what I'm going
to be, from one minute to another! However, I've got back to my right
size: the next thing is, to get into that beautiful garden–how IS that
to be done, I wonder?' As she said this, she came suddenly upon an open
place, with a little house in it about four feet high. 'Whoever lives
there,' thought Alice, 'it'll never do to come upon them THIS size: why,
I should frighten them out of their wits!' So she began nibbling at the
righthand bit again, and did not venture to go near the house till she
had brought herself down to nine inches high.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-224
text: CHAPTER VI. Pig and Pepper
caption: CHAPTER VI. Pig and Pepper

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-225
text:
For a minute or two she stood looking at the house, and wondering what
to do next, when suddenly a footman in livery came running out of the
wood–(she considered him to be a footman because he was in livery:
otherwise, judging by his face only, she would have called him a
fish)–and rapped loudly at the door with his knuckles. It was opened
by another footman in livery, with a round face, and large eyes like a
frog; and both footmen, Alice noticed, had powdered hair that curled all
over their heads. She felt very curious to know what it was all about,
and crept a little way out of the wood to listen.
caption:
For a minute or two she stood looking at the house, and wondering what
to do next, when suddenly a footman in livery came running out of the
wood–(she considered him to be a footman because he was in livery:
otherwise, judging by his face only, she would have called him a
fish)–and rapped loudly at the door with his knuckles. It was opened
by another footman in livery, with a round face, and large eyes like a
frog; and both footmen, Alice noticed, had powdered hair that curled all
over their heads. She felt very curious to know what it was all about,
and crept a little way out of the wood to listen.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-226
text:
The Fish-Footman began by producing from under his arm a great letter,
nearly as large as himself, and this he handed over to the other,
saying, in a solemn tone, 'For the Duchess. An invitation from the Queen
to play croquet.' The Frog-Footman repeated, in the same solemn tone,
only changing the order of the words a little, 'From the Queen. An
invitation for the Duchess to play croquet.'
caption:
The Fish-Footman began by producing from under his arm a great letter,
nearly as large as himself, and this he handed over to the other,
saying, in a solemn tone, 'For the Duchess. An invitation from the Queen
to play croquet.' The Frog-Footman repeated, in the same solemn tone,
only changing the order of the words a little, 'From the Queen. An
invitation for the Duchess to play croquet.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-227
text: Then they both bowed low, and their curls got entangled together.
caption: Then they both bowed low, and their curls got entangled together.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-228
text:
Alice laughed so much at this, that she had to run back into the
wood for fear of their hearing her; and when she next peeped out the
Fish-Footman was gone, and the other was sitting on the ground near the
door, staring stupidly up into the sky.
caption:
Alice laughed so much at this, that she had to run back into the
wood for fear of their hearing her; and when she next peeped out the
Fish-Footman was gone, and the other was sitting on the ground near the
door, staring stupidly up into the sky.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-229
text: Alice went timidly up to the door, and knocked.
caption: Alice went timidly up to the door, and knocked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-230
text:
'There's no sort of use in knocking,' said the Footman, 'and that for
two reasons. First, because I'm on the same side of the door as you
are; secondly, because they're making such a noise inside, no one could
possibly hear you.' And certainly there was a most extraordinary noise
going on within–a constant howling and sneezing, and every now and then
a great crash, as if a dish or kettle had been broken to pieces.
caption:
'There's no sort of use in knocking,' said the Footman, 'and that for
two reasons. First, because I'm on the same side of the door as you
are; secondly, because they're making such a noise inside, no one could
possibly hear you.' And certainly there was a most extraordinary noise
going on within–a constant howling and sneezing, and every now and then
a great crash, as if a dish or kettle had been broken to pieces.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-231
text: 'Please, then,' said Alice, 'how am I to get in?'
caption: 'Please, then,' said Alice, 'how am I to get in?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-232
text:
'There might be some sense in your knocking,' the Footman went on
without attending to her, 'if we had the door between us. For instance,
if you were INSIDE, you might knock, and I could let you out, you know.'
He was looking up into the sky all the time he was speaking, and this
Alice thought decidedly uncivil. 'But perhaps he can't help it,' she
said to herself; 'his eyes are so VERY nearly at the top of his head.
But at any rate he might answer questions.–How am I to get in?' she
repeated, aloud.
caption:
'There might be some sense in your knocking,' the Footman went on
without attending to her, 'if we had the door between us. For instance,
if you were INSIDE, you might knock, and I could let you out, you know.'
He was looking up into the sky all the time he was speaking, and this
Alice thought decidedly uncivil. 'But perhaps he can't help it,' she
said to herself; 'his eyes are so VERY nearly at the top of his head.
But at any rate he might answer questions.–How am I to get in?' she
repeated, aloud.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-233
text: 'I shall sit here,' the Footman remarked, 'till tomorrow–'
caption: 'I shall sit here,' the Footman remarked, 'till tomorrow–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-234
text:
At this moment the door of the house opened, and a large plate came
skimming out, straight at the Footman's head: it just grazed his nose,
and broke to pieces against one of the trees behind him.
caption:
At this moment the door of the house opened, and a large plate came
skimming out, straight at the Footman's head: it just grazed his nose,
and broke to pieces against one of the trees behind him.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-235
text:
'–or next day, maybe,' the Footman continued in the same tone, exactly
as if nothing had happened.
caption:
'–or next day, maybe,' the Footman continued in the same tone, exactly
as if nothing had happened.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-236
text: 'How am I to get in?' asked Alice again, in a louder tone.
caption: 'How am I to get in?' asked Alice again, in a louder tone.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-237
text:
'ARE you to get in at all?' said the Footman. 'That's the first
question, you know.'
caption:
'ARE you to get in at all?' said the Footman. 'That's the first
question, you know.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-238
text:
It was, no doubt: only Alice did not like to be told so. 'It's really
dreadful,' she muttered to herself, 'the way all the creatures argue.
It's enough to drive one crazy!'
caption:
It was, no doubt: only Alice did not like to be told so. 'It's really
dreadful,' she muttered to herself, 'the way all the creatures argue.
It's enough to drive one crazy!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-239
text:
The Footman seemed to think this a good opportunity for repeating his
remark, with variations. 'I shall sit here,' he said, 'on and off, for
days and days.'
caption:
The Footman seemed to think this a good opportunity for repeating his
remark, with variations. 'I shall sit here,' he said, 'on and off, for
days and days.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-240
text: 'But what am I to do?' said Alice.
caption: 'But what am I to do?' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-241
text: 'Anything you like,' said the Footman, and began whistling.
caption: 'Anything you like,' said the Footman, and began whistling.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-242
text:
'Oh, there's no use in talking to him,' said Alice desperately: 'he's
perfectly idiotic!' And she opened the door and went in.
caption:
'Oh, there's no use in talking to him,' said Alice desperately: 'he's
perfectly idiotic!' And she opened the door and went in.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-243
text:
The door led right into a large kitchen, which was full of smoke from
one end to the other: the Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool in
the middle, nursing a baby; the cook was leaning over the fire, stirring
a large cauldron which seemed to be full of soup.
caption:
The door led right into a large kitchen, which was full of smoke from
one end to the other: the Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool in
the middle, nursing a baby; the cook was leaning over the fire, stirring
a large cauldron which seemed to be full of soup.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-244
text:
'There's certainly too much pepper in that soup!' Alice said to herself,
as well as she could for sneezing.
caption:
'There's certainly too much pepper in that soup!' Alice said to herself,
as well as she could for sneezing.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-245
text:
There was certainly too much of it in the air. Even the Duchess
sneezed occasionally; and as for the baby, it was sneezing and howling
alternately without a moment's pause. The only things in the kitchen
that did not sneeze, were the cook, and a large cat which was sitting on
the hearth and grinning from ear to ear.
caption:
There was certainly too much of it in the air. Even the Duchess
sneezed occasionally; and as for the baby, it was sneezing and howling
alternately without a moment's pause. The only things in the kitchen
that did not sneeze, were the cook, and a large cat which was sitting on
the hearth and grinning from ear to ear.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-246
text:
'Please would you tell me,' said Alice, a little timidly, for she was
not quite sure whether it was good manners for her to speak first, 'why
your cat grins like that?'
caption:
'Please would you tell me,' said Alice, a little timidly, for she was
not quite sure whether it was good manners for her to speak first, 'why
your cat grins like that?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-247
text: 'It's a Cheshire cat,' said the Duchess, 'and that's why. Pig!'
caption: 'It's a Cheshire cat,' said the Duchess, 'and that's why. Pig!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-248
text:
She said the last word with such sudden violence that Alice quite
jumped; but she saw in another moment that it was addressed to the baby,
and not to her, so she took courage, and went on again:–
caption:
She said the last word with such sudden violence that Alice quite
jumped; but she saw in another moment that it was addressed to the baby,
and not to her, so she took courage, and went on again:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-249
text:
'I didn't know that Cheshire cats always grinned; in fact, I didn't know
that cats COULD grin.'
caption:
'I didn't know that Cheshire cats always grinned; in fact, I didn't know
that cats COULD grin.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-250
text: 'They all can,' said the Duchess; 'and most of 'em do.'
caption: 'They all can,' said the Duchess; 'and most of 'em do.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-251
text:
'I don't know of any that do,' Alice said very politely, feeling quite
pleased to have got into a conversation.
caption:
'I don't know of any that do,' Alice said very politely, feeling quite
pleased to have got into a conversation.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-252
text: 'You don't know much,' said the Duchess; 'and that's a fact.'
caption: 'You don't know much,' said the Duchess; 'and that's a fact.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-253
text:
Alice did not at all like the tone of this remark, and thought it would
be as well to introduce some other subject of conversation. While she
was trying to fix on one, the cook took the cauldron of soup off the
fire, and at once set to work throwing everything within her reach at
the Duchess and the baby–the fire-irons came first; then followed a
shower of saucepans, plates, and dishes. The Duchess took no notice of
them even when they hit her; and the baby was howling so much already,
that it was quite impossible to say whether the blows hurt it or not.
caption:
Alice did not at all like the tone of this remark, and thought it would
be as well to introduce some other subject of conversation. While she
was trying to fix on one, the cook took the cauldron of soup off the
fire, and at once set to work throwing everything within her reach at
the Duchess and the baby–the fire-irons came first; then followed a
shower of saucepans, plates, and dishes. The Duchess took no notice of
them even when they hit her; and the baby was howling so much already,
that it was quite impossible to say whether the blows hurt it or not.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-254
text:
'Oh, PLEASE mind what you're doing!' cried Alice, jumping up and down in
an agony of terror. 'Oh, there goes his PRECIOUS nose'; as an unusually
large saucepan flew close by it, and very nearly carried it off.
caption:
'Oh, PLEASE mind what you're doing!' cried Alice, jumping up and down in
an agony of terror. 'Oh, there goes his PRECIOUS nose'; as an unusually
large saucepan flew close by it, and very nearly carried it off.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-255
text:
'If everybody minded their own business,' the Duchess said in a hoarse
growl, 'the world would go round a deal faster than it does.'
caption:
'If everybody minded their own business,' the Duchess said in a hoarse
growl, 'the world would go round a deal faster than it does.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-256
text:
'Which would NOT be an advantage,' said Alice, who felt very glad to get
an opportunity of showing off a little of her knowledge. 'Just think of
what work it would make with the day and night! You see the earth takes
twenty-four hours to turn round on its axis–'
caption:
'Which would NOT be an advantage,' said Alice, who felt very glad to get
an opportunity of showing off a little of her knowledge. 'Just think of
what work it would make with the day and night! You see the earth takes
twenty-four hours to turn round on its axis–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-257
text: 'Talking of axes,' said the Duchess, 'chop off her head!'
caption: 'Talking of axes,' said the Duchess, 'chop off her head!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-258
text:
Alice glanced rather anxiously at the cook, to see if she meant to take
the hint; but the cook was busily stirring the soup, and seemed not to
be listening, so she went on again: 'Twenty-four hours, I THINK; or is
it twelve? I–'
caption:
Alice glanced rather anxiously at the cook, to see if she meant to take
the hint; but the cook was busily stirring the soup, and seemed not to
be listening, so she went on again: 'Twenty-four hours, I THINK; or is
it twelve? I–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-259
text:
'Oh, don't bother ME,' said the Duchess; 'I never could abide figures!'
And with that she began nursing her child again, singing a sort of
lullaby to it as she did so, and giving it a violent shake at the end of
every line:
caption:
'Oh, don't bother ME,' said the Duchess; 'I never could abide figures!'
And with that she began nursing her child again, singing a sort of
lullaby to it as she did so, and giving it a violent shake at the end of
every line:

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-260
text:
'Speak roughly to your little boy,
    And beat him when he sneezes:
   He only does it to annoy,
    Because he knows it teases.'
caption:
'Speak roughly to your little boy,
    And beat him when he sneezes:
   He only does it to annoy,
    Because he knows it teases.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-261
text: CHORUS.
caption: CHORUS.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-262
text: (In which the cook and the baby joined):–
caption: (In which the cook and the baby joined):–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-263
text: 'Wow! wow! wow!'
caption: 'Wow! wow! wow!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-264
text:
While the Duchess sang the second verse of the song, she kept tossing
the baby violently up and down, and the poor little thing howled so,
that Alice could hardly hear the words:–
caption:
While the Duchess sang the second verse of the song, she kept tossing
the baby violently up and down, and the poor little thing howled so,
that Alice could hardly hear the words:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-265
text:
'I speak severely to my boy,
    I beat him when he sneezes;
   For he can thoroughly enjoy
    The pepper when he pleases!'
caption:
'I speak severely to my boy,
    I beat him when he sneezes;
   For he can thoroughly enjoy
    The pepper when he pleases!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-266
text: CHORUS.
caption: CHORUS.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-267
text: 'Wow! wow! wow!'
caption: 'Wow! wow! wow!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-268
text:
'Here! you may nurse it a bit, if you like!' the Duchess said to Alice,
flinging the baby at her as she spoke. 'I must go and get ready to play
croquet with the Queen,' and she hurried out of the room. The cook threw
a frying-pan after her as she went out, but it just missed her.
caption:
'Here! you may nurse it a bit, if you like!' the Duchess said to Alice,
flinging the baby at her as she spoke. 'I must go and get ready to play
croquet with the Queen,' and she hurried out of the room. The cook threw
a frying-pan after her as she went out, but it just missed her.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-269
text:
Alice caught the baby with some difficulty, as it was a queer-shaped
little creature, and held out its arms and legs in all directions, 'just
like a star-fish,' thought Alice. The poor little thing was snorting
like a steam-engine when she caught it, and kept doubling itself up and
straightening itself out again, so that altogether, for the first minute
or two, it was as much as she could do to hold it.
caption:
Alice caught the baby with some difficulty, as it was a queer-shaped
little creature, and held out its arms and legs in all directions, 'just
like a star-fish,' thought Alice. The poor little thing was snorting
like a steam-engine when she caught it, and kept doubling itself up and
straightening itself out again, so that altogether, for the first minute
or two, it was as much as she could do to hold it.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-270
text:
As soon as she had made out the proper way of nursing it, (which was to
twist it up into a sort of knot, and then keep tight hold of its right
ear and left foot, so as to prevent its undoing itself,) she carried
it out into the open air. 'IF I don't take this child away with me,'
thought Alice, 'they're sure to kill it in a day or two: wouldn't it be
murder to leave it behind?' She said the last words out loud, and the
little thing grunted in reply (it had left off sneezing by this time).
'Don't grunt,' said Alice; 'that's not at all a proper way of expressing
yourself.'
caption:
As soon as she had made out the proper way of nursing it, (which was to
twist it up into a sort of knot, and then keep tight hold of its right
ear and left foot, so as to prevent its undoing itself,) she carried
it out into the open air. 'IF I don't take this child away with me,'
thought Alice, 'they're sure to kill it in a day or two: wouldn't it be
murder to leave it behind?' She said the last words out loud, and the
little thing grunted in reply (it had left off sneezing by this time).
'Don't grunt,' said Alice; 'that's not at all a proper way of expressing
yourself.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-271
text:
The baby grunted again, and Alice looked very anxiously into its face to
see what was the matter with it. There could be no doubt that it had
a VERY turn-up nose, much more like a snout than a real nose; also its
eyes were getting extremely small for a baby: altogether Alice did not
like the look of the thing at all. 'But perhaps it was only sobbing,'
she thought, and looked into its eyes again, to see if there were any
tears.
caption:
The baby grunted again, and Alice looked very anxiously into its face to
see what was the matter with it. There could be no doubt that it had
a VERY turn-up nose, much more like a snout than a real nose; also its
eyes were getting extremely small for a baby: altogether Alice did not
like the look of the thing at all. 'But perhaps it was only sobbing,'
she thought, and looked into its eyes again, to see if there were any
tears.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-272
text:
No, there were no tears. 'If you're going to turn into a pig, my dear,'
said Alice, seriously, 'I'll have nothing more to do with you. Mind
now!' The poor little thing sobbed again (or grunted, it was impossible
to say which), and they went on for some while in silence.
caption:
No, there were no tears. 'If you're going to turn into a pig, my dear,'
said Alice, seriously, 'I'll have nothing more to do with you. Mind
now!' The poor little thing sobbed again (or grunted, it was impossible
to say which), and they went on for some while in silence.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-273
text:
Alice was just beginning to think to herself, 'Now, what am I to do with
this creature when I get it home?' when it grunted again, so violently,
that she looked down into its face in some alarm. This time there could
be NO mistake about it: it was neither more nor less than a pig, and she
felt that it would be quite absurd for her to carry it further.
caption:
Alice was just beginning to think to herself, 'Now, what am I to do with
this creature when I get it home?' when it grunted again, so violently,
that she looked down into its face in some alarm. This time there could
be NO mistake about it: it was neither more nor less than a pig, and she
felt that it would be quite absurd for her to carry it further.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-274
text:
So she set the little creature down, and felt quite relieved to see
it trot away quietly into the wood. 'If it had grown up,' she said
to herself, 'it would have made a dreadfully ugly child: but it makes
rather a handsome pig, I think.' And she began thinking over other
children she knew, who might do very well as pigs, and was just saying
to herself, 'if one only knew the right way to change them–' when she
was a little startled by seeing the Cheshire Cat sitting on a bough of a
tree a few yards off.
caption:
So she set the little creature down, and felt quite relieved to see
it trot away quietly into the wood. 'If it had grown up,' she said
to herself, 'it would have made a dreadfully ugly child: but it makes
rather a handsome pig, I think.' And she began thinking over other
children she knew, who might do very well as pigs, and was just saying
to herself, 'if one only knew the right way to change them–' when she
was a little startled by seeing the Cheshire Cat sitting on a bough of a
tree a few yards off.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-275
text:
The Cat only grinned when it saw Alice. It looked good-natured, she
thought: still it had VERY long claws and a great many teeth, so she
felt that it ought to be treated with respect.
caption:
The Cat only grinned when it saw Alice. It looked good-natured, she
thought: still it had VERY long claws and a great many teeth, so she
felt that it ought to be treated with respect.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-276
text:
'Cheshire Puss,' she began, rather timidly, as she did not at all know
whether it would like the name: however, it only grinned a little wider.
'Come, it's pleased so far,' thought Alice, and she went on. 'Would you
tell me, please, which way I ought to go from here?'
caption:
'Cheshire Puss,' she began, rather timidly, as she did not at all know
whether it would like the name: however, it only grinned a little wider.
'Come, it's pleased so far,' thought Alice, and she went on. 'Would you
tell me, please, which way I ought to go from here?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-277
text: 'That depends a good deal on where you want to get to,' said the Cat.
caption: 'That depends a good deal on where you want to get to,' said the Cat.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-278
text: 'I don't much care where–' said Alice.
caption: 'I don't much care where–' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-279
text: 'Then it doesn't matter which way you go,' said the Cat.
caption: 'Then it doesn't matter which way you go,' said the Cat.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-280
text: '–so long as I get SOMEWHERE,' Alice added as an explanation.
caption: '–so long as I get SOMEWHERE,' Alice added as an explanation.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-281
text:
'Oh, you're sure to do that,' said the Cat, 'if you only walk long
enough.'
caption:
'Oh, you're sure to do that,' said the Cat, 'if you only walk long
enough.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-282
text:
Alice felt that this could not be denied, so she tried another question.
'What sort of people live about here?'
caption:
Alice felt that this could not be denied, so she tried another question.
'What sort of people live about here?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-283
text:
'In THAT direction,' the Cat said, waving its right paw round, 'lives
a Hatter: and in THAT direction,' waving the other paw, 'lives a March
Hare. Visit either you like: they're both mad.'
caption:
'In THAT direction,' the Cat said, waving its right paw round, 'lives
a Hatter: and in THAT direction,' waving the other paw, 'lives a March
Hare. Visit either you like: they're both mad.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-284
text: 'But I don't want to go among mad people,' Alice remarked.
caption: 'But I don't want to go among mad people,' Alice remarked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-285
text:
'Oh, you can't help that,' said the Cat: 'we're all mad here. I'm mad.
You're mad.'
caption:
'Oh, you can't help that,' said the Cat: 'we're all mad here. I'm mad.
You're mad.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-286
text: 'How do you know I'm mad?' said Alice.
caption: 'How do you know I'm mad?' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-287
text: 'You must be,' said the Cat, 'or you wouldn't have come here.'
caption: 'You must be,' said the Cat, 'or you wouldn't have come here.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-288
text:
Alice didn't think that proved it at all; however, she went on 'And how
do you know that you're mad?'
caption:
Alice didn't think that proved it at all; however, she went on 'And how
do you know that you're mad?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-289
text: 'To begin with,' said the Cat, 'a dog's not mad. You grant that?'
caption: 'To begin with,' said the Cat, 'a dog's not mad. You grant that?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-290
text: 'I suppose so,' said Alice.
caption: 'I suppose so,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-291
text:
'Well, then,' the Cat went on, 'you see, a dog growls when it's angry,
and wags its tail when it's pleased. Now I growl when I'm pleased, and
wag my tail when I'm angry. Therefore I'm mad.'
caption:
'Well, then,' the Cat went on, 'you see, a dog growls when it's angry,
and wags its tail when it's pleased. Now I growl when I'm pleased, and
wag my tail when I'm angry. Therefore I'm mad.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-292
text: 'I call it purring, not growling,' said Alice.
caption: 'I call it purring, not growling,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-293
text:
'Call it what you like,' said the Cat. 'Do you play croquet with the
Queen to-day?'
caption:
'Call it what you like,' said the Cat. 'Do you play croquet with the
Queen to-day?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-294
text:
'I should like it very much,' said Alice, 'but I haven't been invited
yet.'
caption:
'I should like it very much,' said Alice, 'but I haven't been invited
yet.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-295
text: 'You'll see me there,' said the Cat, and vanished.
caption: 'You'll see me there,' said the Cat, and vanished.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-296
text:
Alice was not much surprised at this, she was getting so used to queer
things happening. While she was looking at the place where it had been,
it suddenly appeared again.
caption:
Alice was not much surprised at this, she was getting so used to queer
things happening. While she was looking at the place where it had been,
it suddenly appeared again.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-297
text:
'By-the-bye, what became of the baby?' said the Cat. 'I'd nearly
forgotten to ask.'
caption:
'By-the-bye, what became of the baby?' said the Cat. 'I'd nearly
forgotten to ask.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-298
text:
'It turned into a pig,' Alice quietly said, just as if it had come back
in a natural way.
caption:
'It turned into a pig,' Alice quietly said, just as if it had come back
in a natural way.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-299
text: 'I thought it would,' said the Cat, and vanished again.
caption: 'I thought it would,' said the Cat, and vanished again.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-300
text:
Alice waited a little, half expecting to see it again, but it did not
appear, and after a minute or two she walked on in the direction in
which the March Hare was said to live. 'I've seen hatters before,' she
said to herself; 'the March Hare will be much the most interesting, and
perhaps as this is May it won't be raving mad–at least not so mad as
it was in March.' As she said this, she looked up, and there was the Cat
again, sitting on a branch of a tree.
caption:
Alice waited a little, half expecting to see it again, but it did not
appear, and after a minute or two she walked on in the direction in
which the March Hare was said to live. 'I've seen hatters before,' she
said to herself; 'the March Hare will be much the most interesting, and
perhaps as this is May it won't be raving mad–at least not so mad as
it was in March.' As she said this, she looked up, and there was the Cat
again, sitting on a branch of a tree.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-301
text: 'Did you say pig, or fig?' said the Cat.
caption: 'Did you say pig, or fig?' said the Cat.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-302
text:
'I said pig,' replied Alice; 'and I wish you wouldn't keep appearing and
vanishing so suddenly: you make one quite giddy.'
caption:
'I said pig,' replied Alice; 'and I wish you wouldn't keep appearing and
vanishing so suddenly: you make one quite giddy.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-303
text:
'All right,' said the Cat; and this time it vanished quite slowly,
beginning with the end of the tail, and ending with the grin, which
remained some time after the rest of it had gone.
caption:
'All right,' said the Cat; and this time it vanished quite slowly,
beginning with the end of the tail, and ending with the grin, which
remained some time after the rest of it had gone.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-304
text:
'Well! I've often seen a cat without a grin,' thought Alice; 'but a grin
without a cat! It's the most curious thing I ever saw in my life!'
caption:
'Well! I've often seen a cat without a grin,' thought Alice; 'but a grin
without a cat! It's the most curious thing I ever saw in my life!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-305
text:
She had not gone much farther before she came in sight of the house
of the March Hare: she thought it must be the right house, because the
chimneys were shaped like ears and the roof was thatched with fur. It
was so large a house, that she did not like to go nearer till she had
nibbled some more of the lefthand bit of mushroom, and raised herself to
about two feet high: even then she walked up towards it rather timidly,
saying to herself 'Suppose it should be raving mad after all! I almost
wish I'd gone to see the Hatter instead!'
caption:
She had not gone much farther before she came in sight of the house
of the March Hare: she thought it must be the right house, because the
chimneys were shaped like ears and the roof was thatched with fur. It
was so large a house, that she did not like to go nearer till she had
nibbled some more of the lefthand bit of mushroom, and raised herself to
about two feet high: even then she walked up towards it rather timidly,
saying to herself 'Suppose it should be raving mad after all! I almost
wish I'd gone to see the Hatter instead!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-306
text: CHAPTER VII. A Mad Tea-Party
caption: CHAPTER VII. A Mad Tea-Party

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-307
text:
There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the
March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting
between them, fast asleep, and the other two were using it as a
cushion, resting their elbows on it, and talking over its head. 'Very
uncomfortable for the Dormouse,' thought Alice; 'only, as it's asleep, I
suppose it doesn't mind.'
caption:
There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the
March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting
between them, fast asleep, and the other two were using it as a
cushion, resting their elbows on it, and talking over its head. 'Very
uncomfortable for the Dormouse,' thought Alice; 'only, as it's asleep, I
suppose it doesn't mind.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-308
text:
The table was a large one, but the three were all crowded together at
one corner of it: 'No room! No room!' they cried out when they saw Alice
coming. 'There's PLENTY of room!' said Alice indignantly, and she sat
down in a large arm-chair at one end of the table.
caption:
The table was a large one, but the three were all crowded together at
one corner of it: 'No room! No room!' they cried out when they saw Alice
coming. 'There's PLENTY of room!' said Alice indignantly, and she sat
