down in a large arm-chair at one end of the table.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-309
text: 'Have some wine,' the March Hare said in an encouraging tone.
caption: 'Have some wine,' the March Hare said in an encouraging tone.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-310
text:
Alice looked all round the table, but there was nothing on it but tea.
'I don't see any wine,' she remarked.
caption:
Alice looked all round the table, but there was nothing on it but tea.
'I don't see any wine,' she remarked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-311
text: 'There isn't any,' said the March Hare.
caption: 'There isn't any,' said the March Hare.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-312
text: 'Then it wasn't very civil of you to offer it,' said Alice angrily.
caption: 'Then it wasn't very civil of you to offer it,' said Alice angrily.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-313
text:
'It wasn't very civil of you to sit down without being invited,' said
the March Hare.
caption:
'It wasn't very civil of you to sit down without being invited,' said
the March Hare.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-314
text:
'I didn't know it was YOUR table,' said Alice; 'it's laid for a great
many more than three.'
caption:
'I didn't know it was YOUR table,' said Alice; 'it's laid for a great
many more than three.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-315
text:
'Your hair wants cutting,' said the Hatter. He had been looking at Alice
for some time with great curiosity, and this was his first speech.
caption:
'Your hair wants cutting,' said the Hatter. He had been looking at Alice
for some time with great curiosity, and this was his first speech.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-316
text:
'You should learn not to make personal remarks,' Alice said with some
severity; 'it's very rude.'
caption:
'You should learn not to make personal remarks,' Alice said with some
severity; 'it's very rude.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-317
text:
The Hatter opened his eyes very wide on hearing this; but all he SAID
was, 'Why is a raven like a writing-desk?'
caption:
The Hatter opened his eyes very wide on hearing this; but all he SAID
was, 'Why is a raven like a writing-desk?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-318
text:
'Come, we shall have some fun now!' thought Alice. 'I'm glad they've
begun asking riddles.–I believe I can guess that,' she added aloud.
caption:
'Come, we shall have some fun now!' thought Alice. 'I'm glad they've
begun asking riddles.–I believe I can guess that,' she added aloud.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-319
text:
'Do you mean that you think you can find out the answer to it?' said the
March Hare.
caption:
'Do you mean that you think you can find out the answer to it?' said the
March Hare.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-320
text: 'Exactly so,' said Alice.
caption: 'Exactly so,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-321
text: 'Then you should say what you mean,' the March Hare went on.
caption: 'Then you should say what you mean,' the March Hare went on.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-322
text:
'I do,' Alice hastily replied; 'at least–at least I mean what I
say–that's the same thing, you know.'
caption:
'I do,' Alice hastily replied; 'at least–at least I mean what I
say–that's the same thing, you know.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-323
text:
'Not the same thing a bit!' said the Hatter. 'You might just as well say
that "I see what I eat" is the same thing as "I eat what I see"!'
caption:
'Not the same thing a bit!' said the Hatter. 'You might just as well say
that "I see what I eat" is the same thing as "I eat what I see"!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-324
text:
'You might just as well say,' added the March Hare, 'that "I like what I
get" is the same thing as "I get what I like"!'
caption:
'You might just as well say,' added the March Hare, 'that "I like what I
get" is the same thing as "I get what I like"!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-325
text:
'You might just as well say,' added the Dormouse, who seemed to be
talking in his sleep, 'that "I breathe when I sleep" is the same thing
as "I sleep when I breathe"!'
caption:
'You might just as well say,' added the Dormouse, who seemed to be
talking in his sleep, 'that "I breathe when I sleep" is the same thing
as "I sleep when I breathe"!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-326
text:
'It IS the same thing with you,' said the Hatter, and here the
conversation dropped, and the party sat silent for a minute, while Alice
thought over all she could remember about ravens and writing-desks,
which wasn't much.
caption:
'It IS the same thing with you,' said the Hatter, and here the
conversation dropped, and the party sat silent for a minute, while Alice
thought over all she could remember about ravens and writing-desks,
which wasn't much.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-327
text:
The Hatter was the first to break the silence. 'What day of the month
is it?' he said, turning to Alice: he had taken his watch out of his
pocket, and was looking at it uneasily, shaking it every now and then,
and holding it to his ear.
caption:
The Hatter was the first to break the silence. 'What day of the month
is it?' he said, turning to Alice: he had taken his watch out of his
pocket, and was looking at it uneasily, shaking it every now and then,
and holding it to his ear.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-328
text: Alice considered a little, and then said 'The fourth.'
caption: Alice considered a little, and then said 'The fourth.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-329
text:
'Two days wrong!' sighed the Hatter. 'I told you butter wouldn't suit
the works!' he added looking angrily at the March Hare.
caption:
'Two days wrong!' sighed the Hatter. 'I told you butter wouldn't suit
the works!' he added looking angrily at the March Hare.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-330
text: 'It was the BEST butter,' the March Hare meekly replied.
caption: 'It was the BEST butter,' the March Hare meekly replied.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-331
text:
'Yes, but some crumbs must have got in as well,' the Hatter grumbled:
'you shouldn't have put it in with the bread-knife.'
caption:
'Yes, but some crumbs must have got in as well,' the Hatter grumbled:
'you shouldn't have put it in with the bread-knife.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-332
text:
The March Hare took the watch and looked at it gloomily: then he dipped
it into his cup of tea, and looked at it again: but he could think of
nothing better to say than his first remark, 'It was the BEST butter,
you know.'
caption:
The March Hare took the watch and looked at it gloomily: then he dipped
it into his cup of tea, and looked at it again: but he could think of
nothing better to say than his first remark, 'It was the BEST butter,
you know.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-333
text:
Alice had been looking over his shoulder with some curiosity. 'What a
funny watch!' she remarked. 'It tells the day of the month, and doesn't
tell what o'clock it is!'
caption:
Alice had been looking over his shoulder with some curiosity. 'What a
funny watch!' she remarked. 'It tells the day of the month, and doesn't
tell what o'clock it is!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-334
text:
'Why should it?' muttered the Hatter. 'Does YOUR watch tell you what
year it is?'
caption:
'Why should it?' muttered the Hatter. 'Does YOUR watch tell you what
year it is?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-335
text:
'Of course not,' Alice replied very readily: 'but that's because it
stays the same year for such a long time together.'
caption:
'Of course not,' Alice replied very readily: 'but that's because it
stays the same year for such a long time together.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-336
text: 'Which is just the case with MINE,' said the Hatter.
caption: 'Which is just the case with MINE,' said the Hatter.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-337
text:
Alice felt dreadfully puzzled. The Hatter's remark seemed to have no
sort of meaning in it, and yet it was certainly English. 'I don't quite
understand you,' she said, as politely as she could.
caption:
Alice felt dreadfully puzzled. The Hatter's remark seemed to have no
sort of meaning in it, and yet it was certainly English. 'I don't quite
understand you,' she said, as politely as she could.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-338
text:
'The Dormouse is asleep again,' said the Hatter, and he poured a little
hot tea upon its nose.
caption:
'The Dormouse is asleep again,' said the Hatter, and he poured a little
hot tea upon its nose.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-339
text:
The Dormouse shook its head impatiently, and said, without opening its
eyes, 'Of course, of course; just what I was going to remark myself.'
caption:
The Dormouse shook its head impatiently, and said, without opening its
eyes, 'Of course, of course; just what I was going to remark myself.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-340
text:
'Have you guessed the riddle yet?' the Hatter said, turning to Alice
again.
caption:
'Have you guessed the riddle yet?' the Hatter said, turning to Alice
again.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-341
text: 'No, I give it up,' Alice replied: 'what's the answer?'
caption: 'No, I give it up,' Alice replied: 'what's the answer?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-342
text: 'I haven't the slightest idea,' said the Hatter.
caption: 'I haven't the slightest idea,' said the Hatter.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-343
text: 'Nor I,' said the March Hare.
caption: 'Nor I,' said the March Hare.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-344
text:
Alice sighed wearily. 'I think you might do something better with the
time,' she said, 'than waste it in asking riddles that have no answers.'
caption:
Alice sighed wearily. 'I think you might do something better with the
time,' she said, 'than waste it in asking riddles that have no answers.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-345
text:
'If you knew Time as well as I do,' said the Hatter, 'you wouldn't talk
about wasting IT. It's HIM.'
caption:
'If you knew Time as well as I do,' said the Hatter, 'you wouldn't talk
about wasting IT. It's HIM.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-346
text: 'I don't know what you mean,' said Alice.
caption: 'I don't know what you mean,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-347
text:
'Of course you don't!' the Hatter said, tossing his head contemptuously.
'I dare say you never even spoke to Time!'
caption:
'Of course you don't!' the Hatter said, tossing his head contemptuously.
'I dare say you never even spoke to Time!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-348
text:
'Perhaps not,' Alice cautiously replied: 'but I know I have to beat time
when I learn music.'
caption:
'Perhaps not,' Alice cautiously replied: 'but I know I have to beat time
when I learn music.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-349
text:
'Ah! that accounts for it,' said the Hatter. 'He won't stand beating.
Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he'd do almost anything
you liked with the clock. For instance, suppose it were nine o'clock in
the morning, just time to begin lessons: you'd only have to whisper a
hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one,
time for dinner!'
caption:
'Ah! that accounts for it,' said the Hatter. 'He won't stand beating.
Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he'd do almost anything
you liked with the clock. For instance, suppose it were nine o'clock in
the morning, just time to begin lessons: you'd only have to whisper a
hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one,
time for dinner!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-350
text: ('I only wish it was,' the March Hare said to itself in a whisper.)
caption: ('I only wish it was,' the March Hare said to itself in a whisper.)

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-351
text:
'That would be grand, certainly,' said Alice thoughtfully: 'but then–I
shouldn't be hungry for it, you know.'
caption:
'That would be grand, certainly,' said Alice thoughtfully: 'but then–I
shouldn't be hungry for it, you know.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-352
text:
'Not at first, perhaps,' said the Hatter: 'but you could keep it to
half-past one as long as you liked.'
caption:
'Not at first, perhaps,' said the Hatter: 'but you could keep it to
half-past one as long as you liked.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-353
text: 'Is that the way YOU manage?' Alice asked.
caption: 'Is that the way YOU manage?' Alice asked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-354
text:
The Hatter shook his head mournfully. 'Not I!' he replied. 'We
quarrelled last March–just before HE went mad, you know–' (pointing
with his tea spoon at the March Hare,) '–it was at the great concert
given by the Queen of Hearts, and I had to sing
caption:
The Hatter shook his head mournfully. 'Not I!' he replied. 'We
quarrelled last March–just before HE went mad, you know–' (pointing
with his tea spoon at the March Hare,) '–it was at the great concert
given by the Queen of Hearts, and I had to sing

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-355
text:
"Twinkle, twinkle, little bat!
     How I wonder what you're at!"
caption:
"Twinkle, twinkle, little bat!
     How I wonder what you're at!"

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-356
text: You know the song, perhaps?'
caption: You know the song, perhaps?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-357
text: 'I've heard something like it,' said Alice.
caption: 'I've heard something like it,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-358
text: 'It goes on, you know,' the Hatter continued, 'in this way:–
caption: 'It goes on, you know,' the Hatter continued, 'in this way:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-359
text:
"Up above the world you fly,
     Like a tea-tray in the sky.
         Twinkle, twinkle–"'
caption:
"Up above the world you fly,
     Like a tea-tray in the sky.
         Twinkle, twinkle–"'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-360
text:
Here the Dormouse shook itself, and began singing in its sleep 'Twinkle,
twinkle, twinkle, twinkle–' and went on so long that they had to pinch
it to make it stop.
caption:
Here the Dormouse shook itself, and began singing in its sleep 'Twinkle,
twinkle, twinkle, twinkle–' and went on so long that they had to pinch
it to make it stop.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-361
text:
'Well, I'd hardly finished the first verse,' said the Hatter, 'when the
Queen jumped up and bawled out, "He's murdering the time! Off with his
head!"'
caption:
'Well, I'd hardly finished the first verse,' said the Hatter, 'when the
Queen jumped up and bawled out, "He's murdering the time! Off with his
head!"'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-362
text: 'How dreadfully savage!' exclaimed Alice.
caption: 'How dreadfully savage!' exclaimed Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-363
text:
'And ever since that,' the Hatter went on in a mournful tone, 'he won't
do a thing I ask! It's always six o'clock now.'
caption:
'And ever since that,' the Hatter went on in a mournful tone, 'he won't
do a thing I ask! It's always six o'clock now.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-364
text:
A bright idea came into Alice's head. 'Is that the reason so many
tea-things are put out here?' she asked.
caption:
A bright idea came into Alice's head. 'Is that the reason so many
tea-things are put out here?' she asked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-365
text:
'Yes, that's it,' said the Hatter with a sigh: 'it's always tea-time,
and we've no time to wash the things between whiles.'
caption:
'Yes, that's it,' said the Hatter with a sigh: 'it's always tea-time,
and we've no time to wash the things between whiles.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-366
text: 'Then you keep moving round, I suppose?' said Alice.
caption: 'Then you keep moving round, I suppose?' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-367
text: 'Exactly so,' said the Hatter: 'as the things get used up.'
caption: 'Exactly so,' said the Hatter: 'as the things get used up.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-368
text:
'But what happens when you come to the beginning again?' Alice ventured
to ask.
caption:
'But what happens when you come to the beginning again?' Alice ventured
to ask.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-369
text:
'Suppose we change the subject,' the March Hare interrupted, yawning.
'I'm getting tired of this. I vote the young lady tells us a story.'
caption:
'Suppose we change the subject,' the March Hare interrupted, yawning.
'I'm getting tired of this. I vote the young lady tells us a story.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-370
text:
'I'm afraid I don't know one,' said Alice, rather alarmed at the
proposal.
caption:
'I'm afraid I don't know one,' said Alice, rather alarmed at the
proposal.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-371
text:
'Then the Dormouse shall!' they both cried. 'Wake up, Dormouse!' And
they pinched it on both sides at once.
caption:
'Then the Dormouse shall!' they both cried. 'Wake up, Dormouse!' And
they pinched it on both sides at once.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-372
text:
The Dormouse slowly opened his eyes. 'I wasn't asleep,' he said in a
hoarse, feeble voice: 'I heard every word you fellows were saying.'
caption:
The Dormouse slowly opened his eyes. 'I wasn't asleep,' he said in a
hoarse, feeble voice: 'I heard every word you fellows were saying.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-373
text: 'Tell us a story!' said the March Hare.
caption: 'Tell us a story!' said the March Hare.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-374
text: 'Yes, please do!' pleaded Alice.
caption: 'Yes, please do!' pleaded Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-375
text:
'And be quick about it,' added the Hatter, 'or you'll be asleep again
before it's done.'
caption:
'And be quick about it,' added the Hatter, 'or you'll be asleep again
before it's done.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-376
text:
'Once upon a time there were three little sisters,' the Dormouse began
in a great hurry; 'and their names were Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie; and
they lived at the bottom of a well–'
caption:
'Once upon a time there were three little sisters,' the Dormouse began
in a great hurry; 'and their names were Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie; and
they lived at the bottom of a well–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-377
text:
'What did they live on?' said Alice, who always took a great interest in
questions of eating and drinking.
caption:
'What did they live on?' said Alice, who always took a great interest in
questions of eating and drinking.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-378
text:
'They lived on treacle,' said the Dormouse, after thinking a minute or
two.
caption:
'They lived on treacle,' said the Dormouse, after thinking a minute or
two.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-379
text:
'They couldn't have done that, you know,' Alice gently remarked; 'they'd
have been ill.'
caption:
'They couldn't have done that, you know,' Alice gently remarked; 'they'd
have been ill.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-380
text: 'So they were,' said the Dormouse; 'VERY ill.'
caption: 'So they were,' said the Dormouse; 'VERY ill.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-381
text:
Alice tried to fancy to herself what such an extraordinary ways of
living would be like, but it puzzled her too much, so she went on: 'But
why did they live at the bottom of a well?'
caption:
Alice tried to fancy to herself what such an extraordinary ways of
living would be like, but it puzzled her too much, so she went on: 'But
why did they live at the bottom of a well?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-382
text: 'Take some more tea,' the March Hare said to Alice, very earnestly.
caption: 'Take some more tea,' the March Hare said to Alice, very earnestly.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-383
text:
'I've had nothing yet,' Alice replied in an offended tone, 'so I can't
take more.'
caption:
'I've had nothing yet,' Alice replied in an offended tone, 'so I can't
take more.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-384
text:
'You mean you can't take LESS,' said the Hatter: 'it's very easy to take
MORE than nothing.'
caption:
'You mean you can't take LESS,' said the Hatter: 'it's very easy to take
MORE than nothing.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-385
text: 'Nobody asked YOUR opinion,' said Alice.
caption: 'Nobody asked YOUR opinion,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-386
text: 'Who's making personal remarks now?' the Hatter asked triumphantly.
caption: 'Who's making personal remarks now?' the Hatter asked triumphantly.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-387
text:
Alice did not quite know what to say to this: so she helped herself
to some tea and bread-and-butter, and then turned to the Dormouse, and
repeated her question. 'Why did they live at the bottom of a well?'
caption:
Alice did not quite know what to say to this: so she helped herself
to some tea and bread-and-butter, and then turned to the Dormouse, and
repeated her question. 'Why did they live at the bottom of a well?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-388
text:
The Dormouse again took a minute or two to think about it, and then
said, 'It was a treacle-well.'
caption:
The Dormouse again took a minute or two to think about it, and then
said, 'It was a treacle-well.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-389
text:
'There's no such thing!' Alice was beginning very angrily, but the
Hatter and the March Hare went 'Sh! sh!' and the Dormouse sulkily
remarked, 'If you can't be civil, you'd better finish the story for
yourself.'
caption:
'There's no such thing!' Alice was beginning very angrily, but the
Hatter and the March Hare went 'Sh! sh!' and the Dormouse sulkily
remarked, 'If you can't be civil, you'd better finish the story for
yourself.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-390
text:
'No, please go on!' Alice said very humbly; 'I won't interrupt again. I
dare say there may be ONE.'
caption:
'No, please go on!' Alice said very humbly; 'I won't interrupt again. I
dare say there may be ONE.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-391
text:
'One, indeed!' said the Dormouse indignantly. However, he consented to
go on. 'And so these three little sisters–they were learning to draw,
you know–'
caption:
'One, indeed!' said the Dormouse indignantly. However, he consented to
go on. 'And so these three little sisters–they were learning to draw,
you know–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-392
text: 'What did they draw?' said Alice, quite forgetting her promise.
caption: 'What did they draw?' said Alice, quite forgetting her promise.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-393
text: 'Treacle,' said the Dormouse, without considering at all this time.
caption: 'Treacle,' said the Dormouse, without considering at all this time.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-394
text:
'I want a clean cup,' interrupted the Hatter: 'let's all move one place
on.'
caption:
'I want a clean cup,' interrupted the Hatter: 'let's all move one place
on.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-395
text:
He moved on as he spoke, and the Dormouse followed him: the March Hare
moved into the Dormouse's place, and Alice rather unwillingly took
the place of the March Hare. The Hatter was the only one who got any
advantage from the change: and Alice was a good deal worse off than
before, as the March Hare had just upset the milk-jug into his plate.
caption:
He moved on as he spoke, and the Dormouse followed him: the March Hare
moved into the Dormouse's place, and Alice rather unwillingly took
the place of the March Hare. The Hatter was the only one who got any
advantage from the change: and Alice was a good deal worse off than
before, as the March Hare had just upset the milk-jug into his plate.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-396
text:
Alice did not wish to offend the Dormouse again, so she began very
cautiously: 'But I don't understand. Where did they draw the treacle
from?'
caption:
Alice did not wish to offend the Dormouse again, so she began very
cautiously: 'But I don't understand. Where did they draw the treacle
from?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-397
text:
'You can draw water out of a water-well,' said the Hatter; 'so I should
think you could draw treacle out of a treacle-well–eh, stupid?'
caption:
'You can draw water out of a water-well,' said the Hatter; 'so I should
think you could draw treacle out of a treacle-well–eh, stupid?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-398
text:
'But they were IN the well,' Alice said to the Dormouse, not choosing to
notice this last remark.
caption:
'But they were IN the well,' Alice said to the Dormouse, not choosing to
notice this last remark.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-399
text: 'Of course they were', said the Dormouse; '–well in.'
caption: 'Of course they were', said the Dormouse; '–well in.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-400
text:
This answer so confused poor Alice, that she let the Dormouse go on for
some time without interrupting it.
caption:
This answer so confused poor Alice, that she let the Dormouse go on for
some time without interrupting it.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-401
text:
'They were learning to draw,' the Dormouse went on, yawning and rubbing
its eyes, for it was getting very sleepy; 'and they drew all manner of
things–everything that begins with an M–'
caption:
'They were learning to draw,' the Dormouse went on, yawning and rubbing
its eyes, for it was getting very sleepy; 'and they drew all manner of
things–everything that begins with an M–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-402
text: 'Why with an M?' said Alice.
caption: 'Why with an M?' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-403
text: 'Why not?' said the March Hare.
caption: 'Why not?' said the March Hare.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-404
text: Alice was silent.
caption: Alice was silent.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-405
text:
The Dormouse had closed its eyes by this time, and was going off into
a doze; but, on being pinched by the Hatter, it woke up again with
a little shriek, and went on: '–that begins with an M, such as
mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness–you know you say
things are "much of a muchness"–did you ever see such a thing as a
drawing of a muchness?'
caption:
The Dormouse had closed its eyes by this time, and was going off into
a doze; but, on being pinched by the Hatter, it woke up again with
a little shriek, and went on: '–that begins with an M, such as
mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness–you know you say
things are "much of a muchness"–did you ever see such a thing as a
drawing of a muchness?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-406
text:
'Really, now you ask me,' said Alice, very much confused, 'I don't
think–'
caption:
'Really, now you ask me,' said Alice, very much confused, 'I don't
think–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-407
text: 'Then you shouldn't talk,' said the Hatter.
caption: 'Then you shouldn't talk,' said the Hatter.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-408
text:
This piece of rudeness was more than Alice could bear: she got up in
great disgust, and walked off; the Dormouse fell asleep instantly, and
neither of the others took the least notice of her going, though she
looked back once or twice, half hoping that they would call after her:
the last time she saw them, they were trying to put the Dormouse into
the teapot.
caption:
This piece of rudeness was more than Alice could bear: she got up in
great disgust, and walked off; the Dormouse fell asleep instantly, and
neither of the others took the least notice of her going, though she
looked back once or twice, half hoping that they would call after her:
the last time she saw them, they were trying to put the Dormouse into
the teapot.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-409
text:
'At any rate I'll never go THERE again!' said Alice as she picked her
way through the wood. 'It's the stupidest tea-party I ever was at in all
my life!'
caption:
'At any rate I'll never go THERE again!' said Alice as she picked her
way through the wood. 'It's the stupidest tea-party I ever was at in all
my life!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-410
text:
Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door
leading right into it. 'That's very curious!' she thought. 'But
everything's curious today. I think I may as well go in at once.' And in
she went.
caption:
Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door
leading right into it. 'That's very curious!' she thought. 'But
everything's curious today. I think I may as well go in at once.' And in
she went.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-411
text:
Once more she found herself in the long hall, and close to the little
glass table. 'Now, I'll manage better this time,' she said to herself,
and began by taking the little golden key, and unlocking the door that
led into the garden. Then she went to work nibbling at the mushroom (she
had kept a piece of it in her pocket) till she was about a foot high:
then she walked down the little passage: and THEN–she found herself at
last in the beautiful garden, among the bright flower-beds and the cool
fountains.
caption:
Once more she found herself in the long hall, and close to the little
glass table. 'Now, I'll manage better this time,' she said to herself,
and began by taking the little golden key, and unlocking the door that
led into the garden. Then she went to work nibbling at the mushroom (she
had kept a piece of it in her pocket) till she was about a foot high:
then she walked down the little passage: and THEN–she found herself at
last in the beautiful garden, among the bright flower-beds and the cool
fountains.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-412
text: CHAPTER VIII. The Queen's Croquet-Ground
caption: CHAPTER VIII. The Queen's Croquet-Ground

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-413
text:
A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses
growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily
painting them red. Alice thought this a very curious thing, and she went
nearer to watch them, and just as she came up to them she heard one of
them say, 'Look out now, Five! Don't go splashing paint over me like
that!'
caption:
A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses
growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily
painting them red. Alice thought this a very curious thing, and she went
nearer to watch them, and just as she came up to them she heard one of
them say, 'Look out now, Five! Don't go splashing paint over me like
that!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-414
text:
'I couldn't help it,' said Five, in a sulky tone; 'Seven jogged my
elbow.'
caption:
'I couldn't help it,' said Five, in a sulky tone; 'Seven jogged my
elbow.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-415
text:
On which Seven looked up and said, 'That's right, Five! Always lay the
blame on others!'
caption:
On which Seven looked up and said, 'That's right, Five! Always lay the
blame on others!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-416
text:
'YOU'D better not talk!' said Five. 'I heard the Queen say only
yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!'
caption:
'YOU'D better not talk!' said Five. 'I heard the Queen say only
yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-417
text: 'What for?' said the one who had spoken first.
caption: 'What for?' said the one who had spoken first.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-418
text: 'That's none of YOUR business, Two!' said Seven.
caption: 'That's none of YOUR business, Two!' said Seven.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-419
text:
'Yes, it IS his business!' said Five, 'and I'll tell him–it was for
bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.'
caption:
'Yes, it IS his business!' said Five, 'and I'll tell him–it was for
bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-420
text:
Seven flung down his brush, and had just begun 'Well, of all the unjust
things–' when his eye chanced to fall upon Alice, as she stood watching
them, and he checked himself suddenly: the others looked round also, and
all of them bowed low.
caption:
Seven flung down his brush, and had just begun 'Well, of all the unjust
things–' when his eye chanced to fall upon Alice, as she stood watching
them, and he checked himself suddenly: the others looked round also, and
all of them bowed low.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-421
text:
'Would you tell me,' said Alice, a little timidly, 'why you are painting
those roses?'
caption:
'Would you tell me,' said Alice, a little timidly, 'why you are painting
those roses?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-422
text:
Five and Seven said nothing, but looked at Two. Two began in a low
voice, 'Why the fact is, you see, Miss, this here ought to have been a
RED rose-tree, and we put a white one in by mistake; and if the Queen
was to find it out, we should all have our heads cut off, you know.
So you see, Miss, we're doing our best, afore she comes, to–' At this
moment Five, who had been anxiously looking across the garden, called
out 'The Queen! The Queen!' and the three gardeners instantly threw
themselves flat upon their faces. There was a sound of many footsteps,
and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.
caption:
Five and Seven said nothing, but looked at Two. Two began in a low
voice, 'Why the fact is, you see, Miss, this here ought to have been a
RED rose-tree, and we put a white one in by mistake; and if the Queen
was to find it out, we should all have our heads cut off, you know.
So you see, Miss, we're doing our best, afore she comes, to–' At this
moment Five, who had been anxiously looking across the garden, called
out 'The Queen! The Queen!' and the three gardeners instantly threw
themselves flat upon their faces. There was a sound of many footsteps,
and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-423
text:
First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like
the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the
corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with
diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did. After these came
the royal children; there were ten of them, and the little dears came
jumping merrily along hand in hand, in couples: they were all ornamented
with hearts. Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens, and among
them Alice recognised the White Rabbit: it was talking in a hurried
nervous manner, smiling at everything that was said, and went by without
noticing her. Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying the King's
crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and, last of all this grand
procession, came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS.
caption:
First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like
the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the
corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with
diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did. After these came
the royal children; there were ten of them, and the little dears came
jumping merrily along hand in hand, in couples: they were all ornamented
with hearts. Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens, and among
them Alice recognised the White Rabbit: it was talking in a hurried
nervous manner, smiling at everything that was said, and went by without
noticing her. Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying the King's
crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and, last of all this grand
procession, came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-424
text:
Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face
like the three gardeners, but she could not remember ever having heard
of such a rule at processions; 'and besides, what would be the use of
a procession,' thought she, 'if people had all to lie down upon their
faces, so that they couldn't see it?' So she stood still where she was,
and waited.
caption:
Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face
like the three gardeners, but she could not remember ever having heard
of such a rule at processions; 'and besides, what would be the use of
a procession,' thought she, 'if people had all to lie down upon their
faces, so that they couldn't see it?' So she stood still where she was,
and waited.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-425
text:
When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked
at her, and the Queen said severely 'Who is this?' She said it to the
Knave of Hearts, who only bowed and smiled in reply.
caption:
When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked
at her, and the Queen said severely 'Who is this?' She said it to the
Knave of Hearts, who only bowed and smiled in reply.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-426
text:
'Idiot!' said the Queen, tossing her head impatiently; and, turning to
Alice, she went on, 'What's your name, child?'
caption:
'Idiot!' said the Queen, tossing her head impatiently; and, turning to
Alice, she went on, 'What's your name, child?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-427
Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-428
text:
'And who are THESE?' said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who
were lying round the rosetree; for, you see, as they were lying on their
faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the
pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or
courtiers, or three of her own children.
caption:
'And who are THESE?' said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who
were lying round the rosetree; for, you see, as they were lying on their
faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the
pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or
courtiers, or three of her own children.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-429
text:
'How should I know?' said Alice, surprised at her own courage. 'It's no
business of MINE.'
caption:
'How should I know?' said Alice, surprised at her own courage. 'It's no
business of MINE.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-430
text:
The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a
moment like a wild beast, screamed 'Off with her head! Off–'
caption:
The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a
moment like a wild beast, screamed 'Off with her head! Off–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-431
text:
'Nonsense!' said Alice, very loudly and decidedly, and the Queen was
silent.
caption:
'Nonsense!' said Alice, very loudly and decidedly, and the Queen was
silent.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-432
text:
The King laid his hand upon her arm, and timidly said 'Consider, my
dear: she is only a child!'
caption:
The King laid his hand upon her arm, and timidly said 'Consider, my
dear: she is only a child!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-433
text:
The Queen turned angrily away from him, and said to the Knave 'Turn them
over!'
caption:
The Queen turned angrily away from him, and said to the Knave 'Turn them
over!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-434
text: The Knave did so, very carefully, with one foot.
caption: The Knave did so, very carefully, with one foot.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-435
text:
'Get up!' said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three
gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen,
the royal children, and everybody else.
caption:
'Get up!' said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three
gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen,
the royal children, and everybody else.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-436
text:
'Leave off that!' screamed the Queen. 'You make me giddy.' And then,
turning to the rose-tree, she went on, 'What HAVE you been doing here?'
caption:
'Leave off that!' screamed the Queen. 'You make me giddy.' And then,
turning to the rose-tree, she went on, 'What HAVE you been doing here?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-437
text:
'May it please your Majesty,' said Two, in a very humble tone, going
down on one knee as he spoke, 'we were trying–'
caption:
'May it please your Majesty,' said Two, in a very humble tone, going
down on one knee as he spoke, 'we were trying–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-438
text:
'I see!' said the Queen, who had meanwhile been examining the roses.
'Off with their heads!' and the procession moved on, three of the
soldiers remaining behind to execute the unfortunate gardeners, who ran
to Alice for protection.
caption:
'I see!' said the Queen, who had meanwhile been examining the roses.
'Off with their heads!' and the procession moved on, three of the
soldiers remaining behind to execute the unfortunate gardeners, who ran
to Alice for protection.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-439
text:
'You shan't be beheaded!' said Alice, and she put them into a large
flower-pot that stood near. The three soldiers wandered about for a
minute or two, looking for them, and then quietly marched off after the
others.
caption:
'You shan't be beheaded!' said Alice, and she put them into a large
flower-pot that stood near. The three soldiers wandered about for a
minute or two, looking for them, and then quietly marched off after the
others.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-440
text: 'Are their heads off?' shouted the Queen.
caption: 'Are their heads off?' shouted the Queen.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-441
text:
'Their heads are gone, if it please your Majesty!' the soldiers shouted
in reply.
caption:
'Their heads are gone, if it please your Majesty!' the soldiers shouted
in reply.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-442
text: 'That's right!' shouted the Queen. 'Can you play croquet?'
caption: 'That's right!' shouted the Queen. 'Can you play croquet?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-443
text:
The soldiers were silent, and looked at Alice, as the question was
evidently meant for her.
caption:
The soldiers were silent, and looked at Alice, as the question was
evidently meant for her.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-444
text: 'Yes!' shouted Alice.
caption: 'Yes!' shouted Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-445
text:
'Come on, then!' roared the Queen, and Alice joined the procession,
wondering very much what would happen next.
caption:
'Come on, then!' roared the Queen, and Alice joined the procession,
wondering very much what would happen next.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-446
text:
'It's–it's a very fine day!' said a timid voice at her side. She was
walking by the White Rabbit, who was peeping anxiously into her face.
caption:
'It's–it's a very fine day!' said a timid voice at her side. She was
walking by the White Rabbit, who was peeping anxiously into her face.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-447
text: 'Very,' said Alice: '–where's the Duchess?'
caption: 'Very,' said Alice: '–where's the Duchess?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-448
text:
'Hush! Hush!' said the Rabbit in a low, hurried tone. He looked
anxiously over his shoulder as he spoke, and then raised himself upon
tiptoe, put his mouth close to her ear, and whispered 'She's under
sentence of execution.'
caption:
'Hush! Hush!' said the Rabbit in a low, hurried tone. He looked
anxiously over his shoulder as he spoke, and then raised himself upon
tiptoe, put his mouth close to her ear, and whispered 'She's under
sentence of execution.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-449
text: 'What for?' said Alice.
caption: 'What for?' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-450
text: 'Did you say "What a pity!"?' the Rabbit asked.
caption: 'Did you say "What a pity!"?' the Rabbit asked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-451
text:
'No, I didn't,' said Alice: 'I don't think it's at all a pity. I said
"What for?"'
caption:
'No, I didn't,' said Alice: 'I don't think it's at all a pity. I said
"What for?"'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-452
text:
'She boxed the Queen's ears–' the Rabbit began. Alice gave a little
scream of laughter. 'Oh, hush!' the Rabbit whispered in a frightened
tone. 'The Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the
Queen said–'
caption:
'She boxed the Queen's ears–' the Rabbit began. Alice gave a little
scream of laughter. 'Oh, hush!' the Rabbit whispered in a frightened
tone. 'The Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the
Queen said–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-453
text:
'Get to your places!' shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and
people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each
other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game
began. Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in
her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs,
the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves
up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.
caption:
'Get to your places!' shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and
people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each
other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game
began. Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in
her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs,
the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves
up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-454
text:
The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo:
she succeeded in getting its body tucked away, comfortably enough, under
her arm, with its legs hanging down, but generally, just as she had got
its neck nicely straightened out, and was going to give the hedgehog a
blow with its head, it WOULD twist itself round and look up in her face,
with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out
laughing: and when she had got its head down, and was going to begin
again, it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled
itself, and was in the act of crawling away: besides all this, there was
generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the
hedgehog to, and, as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up
and walking off to other parts of the ground, Alice soon came to the
conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.
caption:
The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo:
she succeeded in getting its body tucked away, comfortably enough, under
her arm, with its legs hanging down, but generally, just as she had got
its neck nicely straightened out, and was going to give the hedgehog a
blow with its head, it WOULD twist itself round and look up in her face,
with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out
laughing: and when she had got its head down, and was going to begin
again, it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled
itself, and was in the act of crawling away: besides all this, there was
generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the
hedgehog to, and, as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up
and walking off to other parts of the ground, Alice soon came to the
conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-455
text:
The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling
all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short
time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and
shouting 'Off with his head!' or 'Off with her head!' about once in a
minute.
caption:
The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling
all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short
time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and
shouting 'Off with his head!' or 'Off with her head!' about once in a
minute.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-456
text:
Alice began to feel very uneasy: to be sure, she had not as yet had any
dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute,
'and then,' thought she, 'what would become of me? They're dreadfully
fond of beheading people here; the great wonder is, that there's any one
left alive!'
caption:
Alice began to feel very uneasy: to be sure, she had not as yet had any
dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute,
'and then,' thought she, 'what would become of me? They're dreadfully
fond of beheading people here; the great wonder is, that there's any one
left alive!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-457
text:
She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she
could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance
in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it
a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself
'It's the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.'
caption:
She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she
could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance
in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it
a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself
'It's the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-458
text:
'How are you getting on?' said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth
enough for it to speak with.
caption:
'How are you getting on?' said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth
enough for it to speak with.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-459
text:
Alice waited till the eyes appeared, and then nodded. 'It's no use
speaking to it,' she thought, 'till its ears have come, or at least one
of them.' In another minute the whole head appeared, and then Alice put
down her flamingo, and began an account of the game, feeling very glad
she had someone to listen to her. The Cat seemed to think that there was
enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.
caption:
Alice waited till the eyes appeared, and then nodded. 'It's no use
speaking to it,' she thought, 'till its ears have come, or at least one
of them.' In another minute the whole head appeared, and then Alice put
down her flamingo, and began an account of the game, feeling very glad
she had someone to listen to her. The Cat seemed to think that there was
enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-460
text:
'I don't think they play at all fairly,' Alice began, in rather a
complaining tone, 'and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can't hear
oneself speak–and they don't seem to have any rules in particular;
at least, if there are, nobody attends to them–and you've no idea how
confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there's the
arch I've got to go through next walking about at the other end of the
ground–and I should have croqueted the Queen's hedgehog just now, only
it ran away when it saw mine coming!'
caption:
'I don't think they play at all fairly,' Alice began, in rather a
complaining tone, 'and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can't hear
oneself speak–and they don't seem to have any rules in particular;
at least, if there are, nobody attends to them–and you've no idea how
confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there's the
arch I've got to go through next walking about at the other end of the
ground–and I should have croqueted the Queen's hedgehog just now, only
it ran away when it saw mine coming!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-461
text: 'How do you like the Queen?' said the Cat in a low voice.
caption: 'How do you like the Queen?' said the Cat in a low voice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-462
text:
'Not at all,' said Alice: 'she's so extremely–' Just then she noticed
that the Queen was close behind her, listening: so she went on,
'–likely to win, that it's hardly worth while finishing the game.'
caption:
'Not at all,' said Alice: 'she's so extremely–' Just then she noticed
that the Queen was close behind her, listening: so she went on,
'–likely to win, that it's hardly worth while finishing the game.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-463
text: The Queen smiled and passed on.
caption: The Queen smiled and passed on.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-464
text:
'Who ARE you talking to?' said the King, going up to Alice, and looking
at the Cat's head with great curiosity.
caption:
'Who ARE you talking to?' said the King, going up to Alice, and looking
at the Cat's head with great curiosity.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-465
text:
'It's a friend of mine–a Cheshire Cat,' said Alice: 'allow me to
introduce it.'
caption:
'It's a friend of mine–a Cheshire Cat,' said Alice: 'allow me to
introduce it.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-466
text:
'I don't like the look of it at all,' said the King: 'however, it may
kiss my hand if it likes.'
caption:
'I don't like the look of it at all,' said the King: 'however, it may
kiss my hand if it likes.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-467
text: 'I'd rather not,' the Cat remarked.
caption: 'I'd rather not,' the Cat remarked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-468
text:
'Don't be impertinent,' said the King, 'and don't look at me like that!'
He got behind Alice as he spoke.
caption:
'Don't be impertinent,' said the King, 'and don't look at me like that!'
He got behind Alice as he spoke.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-469
text:
'A cat may look at a king,' said Alice. 'I've read that in some book,
but I don't remember where.'
caption:
'A cat may look at a king,' said Alice. 'I've read that in some book,
but I don't remember where.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-470
text:
'Well, it must be removed,' said the King very decidedly, and he called
the Queen, who was passing at the moment, 'My dear! I wish you would
have this cat removed!'
caption:
'Well, it must be removed,' said the King very decidedly, and he called
the Queen, who was passing at the moment, 'My dear! I wish you would
have this cat removed!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-471
text:
The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small.
'Off with his head!' she said, without even looking round.
caption:
The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small.
'Off with his head!' she said, without even looking round.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-472
text:
'I'll fetch the executioner myself,' said the King eagerly, and he
hurried off.
caption:
'I'll fetch the executioner myself,' said the King eagerly, and he
hurried off.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-473
text:
Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going
on, as she heard the Queen's voice in the distance, screaming with
passion. She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be
executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look
of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew
whether it was her turn or not. So she went in search of her hedgehog.
caption:
Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going
on, as she heard the Queen's voice in the distance, screaming with
passion. She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be
executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look
of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew
whether it was her turn or not. So she went in search of her hedgehog.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-474
text:
The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed
to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the
other: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the
other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless
sort of way to fly up into a tree.
caption:
The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed
to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the
other: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the
other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless
sort of way to fly up into a tree.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-475
text:
By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight
was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight: 'but it doesn't
matter much,' thought Alice, 'as all the arches are gone from this side
of the ground.' So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not
escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her
friend.
caption:
By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight
was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight: 'but it doesn't
matter much,' thought Alice, 'as all the arches are gone from this side
of the ground.' So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not
escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her
friend.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-476
text:
When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a
large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between
the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once,
while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.
caption:
When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a
large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between
the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once,
while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-477
text:
The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle
the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they
all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly
what they said.
caption:
The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle
the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they
all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly
what they said.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-478
text:
The executioner's argument was, that you couldn't cut off a head unless
there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a
thing before, and he wasn't going to begin at HIS time of life.
caption:
The executioner's argument was, that you couldn't cut off a head unless
there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a
thing before, and he wasn't going to begin at HIS time of life.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-479
text:
The King's argument was, that anything that had a head could be
beheaded, and that you weren't to talk nonsense.
caption:
The King's argument was, that anything that had a head could be
beheaded, and that you weren't to talk nonsense.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-480
text:
The Queen's argument was, that if something wasn't done about it in less
than no time she'd have everybody executed, all round. (It was this last
remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)
caption:
The Queen's argument was, that if something wasn't done about it in less
than no time she'd have everybody executed, all round. (It was this last
remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-481
text:
Alice could think of nothing else to say but 'It belongs to the Duchess:
you'd better ask HER about it.'
caption:
Alice could think of nothing else to say but 'It belongs to the Duchess:
you'd better ask HER about it.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-482
text:
'She's in prison,' the Queen said to the executioner: 'fetch her here.'
And the executioner went off like an arrow.
caption:
'She's in prison,' the Queen said to the executioner: 'fetch her here.'
And the executioner went off like an arrow.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-483
text:
The Cat's head began fading away the moment he was gone, and,
by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely
disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down
looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.
caption:
The Cat's head began fading away the moment he was gone, and,
by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely
disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down
looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-484
text: CHAPTER IX. The Mock Turtle's Story
caption: CHAPTER IX. The Mock Turtle's Story

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-485
text:
'You can't think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!'
said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice's, and
they walked off together.
caption:
'You can't think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!'
said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice's, and
they walked off together.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-486
text:
Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought
to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so
savage when they met in the kitchen.
caption:
Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought
to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so
savage when they met in the kitchen.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-487
text:
'When I'M a Duchess,' she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone
though), 'I won't have any pepper in my kitchen AT ALL. Soup does very
well without–Maybe it's always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,'
she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of
rule, 'and vinegar that makes them sour–and camomile that makes
them bitter–and–and barley-sugar and such things that make children
sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn't be so
stingy about it, you know–'
caption:
'When I'M a Duchess,' she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone
though), 'I won't have any pepper in my kitchen AT ALL. Soup does very
well without–Maybe it's always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,'
she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of
rule, 'and vinegar that makes them sour–and camomile that makes
them bitter–and–and barley-sugar and such things that make children
sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn't be so
stingy about it, you know–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-488
text:
She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little
startled when she heard her voice close to her ear. 'You're thinking
about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk. I can't
tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in
a bit.'
caption:
She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little
startled when she heard her voice close to her ear. 'You're thinking
about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk. I can't
tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in
a bit.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-489
text: 'Perhaps it hasn't one,' Alice ventured to remark.
caption: 'Perhaps it hasn't one,' Alice ventured to remark.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-490
text:
'Tut, tut, child!' said the Duchess. 'Everything's got a moral, if only
you can find it.' And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice's side as
she spoke.
caption:
'Tut, tut, child!' said the Duchess. 'Everything's got a moral, if only
you can find it.' And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice's side as
she spoke.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-491
text:
Alice did not much like keeping so close to her: first, because the
Duchess was VERY ugly; and secondly, because she was exactly the
right height to rest her chin upon Alice's shoulder, and it was an
uncomfortably sharp chin. However, she did not like to be rude, so she
bore it as well as she could.
caption:
Alice did not much like keeping so close to her: first, because the
Duchess was VERY ugly; and secondly, because she was exactly the
right height to rest her chin upon Alice's shoulder, and it was an
uncomfortably sharp chin. However, she did not like to be rude, so she
bore it as well as she could.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-492
text:
'The game's going on rather better now,' she said, by way of keeping up
the conversation a little.
caption:
'The game's going on rather better now,' she said, by way of keeping up
the conversation a little.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-493
text:
' 'Tis so,' said the Duchess: 'and the moral of that is–"Oh, 'tis love,
'tis love, that makes the world go round!"'
caption:
' 'Tis so,' said the Duchess: 'and the moral of that is–"Oh, 'tis love,
'tis love, that makes the world go round!"'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-494
text:
'Somebody said,' Alice whispered, 'that it's done by everybody minding
their own business!'
caption:
'Somebody said,' Alice whispered, 'that it's done by everybody minding
their own business!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-495
text:
'Ah, well! It means much the same thing,' said the Duchess, digging her
sharp little chin into Alice's shoulder as she added, 'and the moral
of THAT is–"Take care of the sense, and the sounds will take care of
themselves."'
caption:
'Ah, well! It means much the same thing,' said the Duchess, digging her
sharp little chin into Alice's shoulder as she added, 'and the moral
of THAT is–"Take care of the sense, and the sounds will take care of
themselves."'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-496
text: 'How fond she is of finding morals in things!' Alice thought to herself.
caption: 'How fond she is of finding morals in things!' Alice thought to herself.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-497
text:
'I dare say you're wondering why I don't put my arm round your waist,'
the Duchess said after a pause: 'the reason is, that I'm doubtful about
the temper of your flamingo. Shall I try the experiment?'
caption:
'I dare say you're wondering why I don't put my arm round your waist,'
the Duchess said after a pause: 'the reason is, that I'm doubtful about
the temper of your flamingo. Shall I try the experiment?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-498
text:
'HE might bite,' Alice cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to
have the experiment tried.
caption:
'HE might bite,' Alice cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to
have the experiment tried.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-499
text:
'Very true,' said the Duchess: 'flamingoes and mustard both bite. And
the moral of that is–"Birds of a feather flock together."'
caption:
'Very true,' said the Duchess: 'flamingoes and mustard both bite. And
the moral of that is–"Birds of a feather flock together."'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-500
text: 'Only mustard isn't a bird,' Alice remarked.
caption: 'Only mustard isn't a bird,' Alice remarked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-501
text:
'Right, as usual,' said the Duchess: 'what a clear way you have of
putting things!'
caption:
'Right, as usual,' said the Duchess: 'what a clear way you have of
putting things!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-502
text: 'It's a mineral, I THINK,' said Alice.
caption: 'It's a mineral, I THINK,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-503
text:
'Of course it is,' said the Duchess, who seemed ready to agree to
everything that Alice said; 'there's a large mustard-mine near here. And
the moral of that is–"The more there is of mine, the less there is of
yours."'
caption:
'Of course it is,' said the Duchess, who seemed ready to agree to
everything that Alice said; 'there's a large mustard-mine near here. And
the moral of that is–"The more there is of mine, the less there is of
yours."'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-504
text:
'Oh, I know!' exclaimed Alice, who had not attended to this last remark,
'it's a vegetable. It doesn't look like one, but it is.'
caption:
'Oh, I know!' exclaimed Alice, who had not attended to this last remark,
'it's a vegetable. It doesn't look like one, but it is.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-505
text:
'I quite agree with you,' said the Duchess; 'and the moral of that
is–"Be what you would seem to be"–or if you'd like it put more
simply–"Never imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might
appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise
than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise."'
caption:
'I quite agree with you,' said the Duchess; 'and the moral of that
is–"Be what you would seem to be"–or if you'd like it put more
simply–"Never imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might
appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise
than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise."'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-506
text:
'I think I should understand that better,' Alice said very politely, 'if
I had it written down: but I can't quite follow it as you say it.'
caption:
'I think I should understand that better,' Alice said very politely, 'if
I had it written down: but I can't quite follow it as you say it.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-507
text:
'That's nothing to what I could say if I chose,' the Duchess replied, in
a pleased tone.
caption:
'That's nothing to what I could say if I chose,' the Duchess replied, in
a pleased tone.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-508
text:
'Pray don't trouble yourself to say it any longer than that,' said
Alice.
caption:
'Pray don't trouble yourself to say it any longer than that,' said
Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-509
text:
'Oh, don't talk about trouble!' said the Duchess. 'I make you a present
of everything I've said as yet.'
caption:
'Oh, don't talk about trouble!' said the Duchess. 'I make you a present
of everything I've said as yet.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-510
text:
'A cheap sort of present!' thought Alice. 'I'm glad they don't give
birthday presents like that!' But she did not venture to say it out
loud.
caption:
'A cheap sort of present!' thought Alice. 'I'm glad they don't give
birthday presents like that!' But she did not venture to say it out
loud.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-511
text:
'Thinking again?' the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp
little chin.
caption:
'Thinking again?' the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp
little chin.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-512
text:
'I've a right to think,' said Alice sharply, for she was beginning to
feel a little worried.
caption:
'I've a right to think,' said Alice sharply, for she was beginning to
feel a little worried.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-513
text:
'Just about as much right,' said the Duchess, 'as pigs have to fly; and
the m–'
caption:
'Just about as much right,' said the Duchess, 'as pigs have to fly; and
the m–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-514
text:
But here, to Alice's great surprise, the Duchess's voice died away, even
in the middle of her favourite word 'moral,' and the arm that was linked
into hers began to tremble. Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen
in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.
caption:
But here, to Alice's great surprise, the Duchess's voice died away, even
in the middle of her favourite word 'moral,' and the arm that was linked
into hers began to tremble. Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen
in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-515
text: 'A fine day, your Majesty!' the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.
caption: 'A fine day, your Majesty!' the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-516
text:
'Now, I give you fair warning,' shouted the Queen, stamping on the
ground as she spoke; 'either you or your head must be off, and that in
about half no time! Take your choice!'
caption:
'Now, I give you fair warning,' shouted the Queen, stamping on the
ground as she spoke; 'either you or your head must be off, and that in
about half no time! Take your choice!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-517
text: The Duchess took her choice, and was gone in a moment.
caption: The Duchess took her choice, and was gone in a moment.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-518
text:
'Let's go on with the game,' the Queen said to Alice; and Alice was
too much frightened to say a word, but slowly followed her back to the
croquet-ground.
caption:
'Let's go on with the game,' the Queen said to Alice; and Alice was
too much frightened to say a word, but slowly followed her back to the
croquet-ground.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-519
text:
The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen's absence, and were
resting in the shade: however, the moment they saw her, they hurried
back to the game, the Queen merely remarking that a moment's delay would
cost them their lives.
caption:
The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen's absence, and were
resting in the shade: however, the moment they saw her, they hurried
back to the game, the Queen merely remarking that a moment's delay would
cost them their lives.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-520
text:
All the time they were playing the Queen never left off quarrelling with
the other players, and shouting 'Off with his head!' or 'Off with her
head!' Those whom she sentenced were taken into custody by the soldiers,
who of course had to leave off being arches to do this, so that by
the end of half an hour or so there were no arches left, and all the
players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice, were in custody and
under sentence of execution.
caption:
All the time they were playing the Queen never left off quarrelling with
the other players, and shouting 'Off with his head!' or 'Off with her
head!' Those whom she sentenced were taken into custody by the soldiers,
who of course had to leave off being arches to do this, so that by
the end of half an hour or so there were no arches left, and all the
players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice, were in custody and
under sentence of execution.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-521
text:
Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, 'Have
you seen the Mock Turtle yet?'
caption:
Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, 'Have
you seen the Mock Turtle yet?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-522
text: 'No,' said Alice. 'I don't even know what a Mock Turtle is.'
caption: 'No,' said Alice. 'I don't even know what a Mock Turtle is.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-523
text: 'It's the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,' said the Queen.
caption: 'It's the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,' said the Queen.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-524
text: 'I never saw one, or heard of one,' said Alice.
caption: 'I never saw one, or heard of one,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-525
text: 'Come on, then,' said the Queen, 'and he shall tell you his history,'
caption: 'Come on, then,' said the Queen, 'and he shall tell you his history,'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-526
text:
As they walked off together, Alice heard the King say in a low voice,
to the company generally, 'You are all pardoned.' 'Come, THAT'S a good
thing!' she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the
number of executions the Queen had ordered.
caption:
As they walked off together, Alice heard the King say in a low voice,
to the company generally, 'You are all pardoned.' 'Come, THAT'S a good
thing!' she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the
number of executions the Queen had ordered.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-527
text:
They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun.
(IF you don't know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.) 'Up, lazy
thing!' said the Queen, 'and take this young lady to see the Mock
Turtle, and to hear his history. I must go back and see after some
executions I have ordered'; and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with
the Gryphon. Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on
the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go
after that savage Queen: so she waited.
caption:
They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun.
(IF you don't know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.) 'Up, lazy
thing!' said the Queen, 'and take this young lady to see the Mock
Turtle, and to hear his history. I must go back and see after some
executions I have ordered'; and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with
the Gryphon. Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on
the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go
after that savage Queen: so she waited.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-528
text:
The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till
she was out of sight: then it chuckled. 'What fun!' said the Gryphon,
half to itself, half to Alice.
caption:
The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till
she was out of sight: then it chuckled. 'What fun!' said the Gryphon,
half to itself, half to Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-529
text: 'What IS the fun?' said Alice.
caption: 'What IS the fun?' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-530
text:
'Why, SHE,' said the Gryphon. 'It's all her fancy, that: they never
executes nobody, you know. Come on!'
caption:
'Why, SHE,' said the Gryphon. 'It's all her fancy, that: they never
executes nobody, you know. Come on!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-531
text:
'Everybody says "come on!" here,' thought Alice, as she went slowly
after it: 'I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!'
caption:
'Everybody says "come on!" here,' thought Alice, as she went slowly
after it: 'I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-532
text:
They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance,
sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came
nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break. She
pitied him deeply. 'What is his sorrow?' she asked the Gryphon, and the
Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, 'It's all his
fancy, that: he hasn't got no sorrow, you know. Come on!'
caption:
They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance,
sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came
nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break. She
pitied him deeply. 'What is his sorrow?' she asked the Gryphon, and the
Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, 'It's all his
fancy, that: he hasn't got no sorrow, you know. Come on!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-533
text:
So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes
full of tears, but said nothing.
caption:
So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes
full of tears, but said nothing.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-534
text:
'This here young lady,' said the Gryphon, 'she wants for to know your
history, she do.'
caption:
'This here young lady,' said the Gryphon, 'she wants for to know your
history, she do.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-535
text:
'I'll tell it her,' said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow tone: 'sit
down, both of you, and don't speak a word till I've finished.'
caption:
'I'll tell it her,' said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow tone: 'sit
down, both of you, and don't speak a word till I've finished.'
