title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-536
text:
So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. Alice thought to
herself, 'I don't see how he can EVEN finish, if he doesn't begin.' But
she waited patiently.
caption:
So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. Alice thought to
herself, 'I don't see how he can EVEN finish, if he doesn't begin.' But
she waited patiently.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-537
text:
'Once,' said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, 'I was a real
Turtle.'
caption:
'Once,' said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, 'I was a real
Turtle.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-538
text:
These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an
occasional exclamation of 'Hjckrrh!' from the Gryphon, and the constant
heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle. Alice was very nearly getting up and
saying, 'Thank you, sir, for your interesting story,' but she could
not help thinking there MUST be more to come, so she sat still and said
nothing.
caption:
These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an
occasional exclamation of 'Hjckrrh!' from the Gryphon, and the constant
heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle. Alice was very nearly getting up and
saying, 'Thank you, sir, for your interesting story,' but she could
not help thinking there MUST be more to come, so she sat still and said
nothing.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-539
text:
'When we were little,' the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly,
though still sobbing a little now and then, 'we went to school in the
sea. The master was an old Turtle–we used to call him Tortoise–'
caption:
'When we were little,' the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly,
though still sobbing a little now and then, 'we went to school in the
sea. The master was an old Turtle–we used to call him Tortoise–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-540
text: 'Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn't one?' Alice asked.
caption: 'Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn't one?' Alice asked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-541
text:
'We called him Tortoise because he taught us,' said the Mock Turtle
angrily: 'really you are very dull!'
caption:
'We called him Tortoise because he taught us,' said the Mock Turtle
angrily: 'really you are very dull!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-542
text:
'You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question,'
added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor
Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said
to the Mock Turtle, 'Drive on, old fellow! Don't be all day about it!'
and he went on in these words:
caption:
'You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question,'
added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor
Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said
to the Mock Turtle, 'Drive on, old fellow! Don't be all day about it!'
and he went on in these words:

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-543
text: 'Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn't believe it–'
caption: 'Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn't believe it–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-544
text: 'I never said I didn't!' interrupted Alice.
caption: 'I never said I didn't!' interrupted Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-545
text: 'You did,' said the Mock Turtle.
caption: 'You did,' said the Mock Turtle.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-546
text:
'Hold your tongue!' added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again.
The Mock Turtle went on.
caption:
'Hold your tongue!' added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again.
The Mock Turtle went on.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-547
text: 'We had the best of educations–in fact, we went to school every day–'
caption: 'We had the best of educations–in fact, we went to school every day–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-548
text:
'I'VE been to a day-school, too,' said Alice; 'you needn't be so proud
as all that.'
caption:
'I'VE been to a day-school, too,' said Alice; 'you needn't be so proud
as all that.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-549
text: 'With extras?' asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.
caption: 'With extras?' asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-550
text: 'Yes,' said Alice, 'we learned French and music.'
caption: 'Yes,' said Alice, 'we learned French and music.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-551
text: 'And washing?' said the Mock Turtle.
caption: 'And washing?' said the Mock Turtle.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-552
text: 'Certainly not!' said Alice indignantly.
caption: 'Certainly not!' said Alice indignantly.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-553
text:
'Ah! then yours wasn't a really good school,' said the Mock Turtle in
a tone of great relief. 'Now at OURS they had at the end of the bill,
"French, music, AND WASHING–extra."'
caption:
'Ah! then yours wasn't a really good school,' said the Mock Turtle in
a tone of great relief. 'Now at OURS they had at the end of the bill,
"French, music, AND WASHING–extra."'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-554
text:
'You couldn't have wanted it much,' said Alice; 'living at the bottom of
the sea.'
caption:
'You couldn't have wanted it much,' said Alice; 'living at the bottom of
the sea.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-555
text:
'I couldn't afford to learn it.' said the Mock Turtle with a sigh. 'I
only took the regular course.'
caption:
'I couldn't afford to learn it.' said the Mock Turtle with a sigh. 'I
only took the regular course.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-556
text: 'What was that?' inquired Alice.
caption: 'What was that?' inquired Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-557
text:
'Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with,' the Mock Turtle
replied; 'and then the different branches of Arithmetic–Ambition,
Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.'
caption:
'Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with,' the Mock Turtle
replied; 'and then the different branches of Arithmetic–Ambition,
Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-558
text: 'I never heard of "Uglification,"' Alice ventured to say. 'What is it?'
caption: 'I never heard of "Uglification,"' Alice ventured to say. 'What is it?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-559
text:
The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise. 'What! Never heard of
uglifying!' it exclaimed. 'You know what to beautify is, I suppose?'
caption:
The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise. 'What! Never heard of
uglifying!' it exclaimed. 'You know what to beautify is, I suppose?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-560
text: 'Yes,' said Alice doubtfully: 'it means–to–make–anything–prettier.'
caption: 'Yes,' said Alice doubtfully: 'it means–to–make–anything–prettier.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-561
text:
'Well, then,' the Gryphon went on, 'if you don't know what to uglify is,
you ARE a simpleton.'
caption:
'Well, then,' the Gryphon went on, 'if you don't know what to uglify is,
you ARE a simpleton.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-562
text:
Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she
turned to the Mock Turtle, and said 'What else had you to learn?'
caption:
Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she
turned to the Mock Turtle, and said 'What else had you to learn?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-563
text:
'Well, there was Mystery,' the Mock Turtle replied, counting off
the subjects on his flappers, '–Mystery, ancient and modern, with
Seaography: then Drawling–the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel,
that used to come once a week: HE taught us Drawling, Stretching, and
Fainting in Coils.'
caption:
'Well, there was Mystery,' the Mock Turtle replied, counting off
the subjects on his flappers, '–Mystery, ancient and modern, with
Seaography: then Drawling–the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel,
that used to come once a week: HE taught us Drawling, Stretching, and
Fainting in Coils.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-564
text: 'What was THAT like?' said Alice.
caption: 'What was THAT like?' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-565
text:
'Well, I can't show it you myself,' the Mock Turtle said: 'I'm too
stiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it.'
caption:
'Well, I can't show it you myself,' the Mock Turtle said: 'I'm too
stiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-566
text:
'Hadn't time,' said the Gryphon: 'I went to the Classics master, though.
He was an old crab, HE was.'
caption:
'Hadn't time,' said the Gryphon: 'I went to the Classics master, though.
He was an old crab, HE was.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-567
text:
'I never went to him,' the Mock Turtle said with a sigh: 'he taught
Laughing and Grief, they used to say.'
caption:
'I never went to him,' the Mock Turtle said with a sigh: 'he taught
Laughing and Grief, they used to say.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-568
text:
'So he did, so he did,' said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both
creatures hid their faces in their paws.
caption:
'So he did, so he did,' said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both
creatures hid their faces in their paws.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-569
text:
'And how many hours a day did you do lessons?' said Alice, in a hurry to
change the subject.
caption:
'And how many hours a day did you do lessons?' said Alice, in a hurry to
change the subject.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-570
text:
'Ten hours the first day,' said the Mock Turtle: 'nine the next, and so
on.'
caption:
'Ten hours the first day,' said the Mock Turtle: 'nine the next, and so
on.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-571
text: 'What a curious plan!' exclaimed Alice.
caption: 'What a curious plan!' exclaimed Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-572
text:
'That's the reason they're called lessons,' the Gryphon remarked:
'because they lessen from day to day.'
caption:
'That's the reason they're called lessons,' the Gryphon remarked:
'because they lessen from day to day.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-573
text:
This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little
before she made her next remark. 'Then the eleventh day must have been a
holiday?'
caption:
This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little
before she made her next remark. 'Then the eleventh day must have been a
holiday?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-574
text: 'Of course it was,' said the Mock Turtle.
caption: 'Of course it was,' said the Mock Turtle.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-575
text: 'And how did you manage on the twelfth?' Alice went on eagerly.
caption: 'And how did you manage on the twelfth?' Alice went on eagerly.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-576
text:
'That's enough about lessons,' the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided
tone: 'tell her something about the games now.'
caption:
'That's enough about lessons,' the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided
tone: 'tell her something about the games now.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-577
text: CHAPTER X. The Lobster Quadrille
caption: CHAPTER X. The Lobster Quadrille

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-578
text:
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across
his eyes. He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or
two sobs choked his voice. 'Same as if he had a bone in his throat,'
said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him in
the back. At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears
running down his cheeks, he went on again:–
caption:
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across
his eyes. He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or
two sobs choked his voice. 'Same as if he had a bone in his throat,'
said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him in
the back. At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears
running down his cheeks, he went on again:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-579
text:
'You may not have lived much under the sea–' ('I haven't,' said
Alice)–'and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster–'
(Alice began to say 'I once tasted–' but checked herself hastily, and
said 'No, never') '–so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a
Lobster Quadrille is!'
caption:
'You may not have lived much under the sea–' ('I haven't,' said
Alice)–'and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster–'
(Alice began to say 'I once tasted–' but checked herself hastily, and
said 'No, never') '–so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a
Lobster Quadrille is!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-580
text: 'No, indeed,' said Alice. 'What sort of a dance is it?'
caption: 'No, indeed,' said Alice. 'What sort of a dance is it?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-581
text:
'Why,' said the Gryphon, 'you first form into a line along the
sea-shore–'
caption:
'Why,' said the Gryphon, 'you first form into a line along the
sea-shore–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-582
text:
'Two lines!' cried the Mock Turtle. 'Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on;
then, when you've cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way–'
caption:
'Two lines!' cried the Mock Turtle. 'Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on;
then, when you've cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-583
text: 'THAT generally takes some time,' interrupted the Gryphon.
caption: 'THAT generally takes some time,' interrupted the Gryphon.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-584
text: '–you advance twice–'
caption: '–you advance twice–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-585
text: 'Each with a lobster as a partner!' cried the Gryphon.
caption: 'Each with a lobster as a partner!' cried the Gryphon.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-586
text: 'Of course,' the Mock Turtle said: 'advance twice, set to partners–'
caption: 'Of course,' the Mock Turtle said: 'advance twice, set to partners–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-587
text: '–change lobsters, and retire in same order,' continued the Gryphon.
caption: '–change lobsters, and retire in same order,' continued the Gryphon.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-588
text: 'Then, you know,' the Mock Turtle went on, 'you throw the–'
caption: 'Then, you know,' the Mock Turtle went on, 'you throw the–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-589
text: 'The lobsters!' shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.
caption: 'The lobsters!' shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-590
text: '–as far out to sea as you can–'
caption: '–as far out to sea as you can–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-591
text: 'Swim after them!' screamed the Gryphon.
caption: 'Swim after them!' screamed the Gryphon.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-592
text:
'Turn a somersault in the sea!' cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly
about.
caption:
'Turn a somersault in the sea!' cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly
about.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-593
text: 'Change lobsters again!' yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.
caption: 'Change lobsters again!' yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-594
text:
'Back to land again, and that's all the first figure,' said the Mock
Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been
jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly
and quietly, and looked at Alice.
caption:
'Back to land again, and that's all the first figure,' said the Mock
Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been
jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly
and quietly, and looked at Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-595
text: 'It must be a very pretty dance,' said Alice timidly.
caption: 'It must be a very pretty dance,' said Alice timidly.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-596
text: 'Would you like to see a little of it?' said the Mock Turtle.
caption: 'Would you like to see a little of it?' said the Mock Turtle.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-597
text: 'Very much indeed,' said Alice.
caption: 'Very much indeed,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-598
text:
'Come, let's try the first figure!' said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon.
'We can do without lobsters, you know. Which shall sing?'
caption:
'Come, let's try the first figure!' said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon.
'We can do without lobsters, you know. Which shall sing?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-599
text: 'Oh, YOU sing,' said the Gryphon. 'I've forgotten the words.'
caption: 'Oh, YOU sing,' said the Gryphon. 'I've forgotten the words.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-600
text:
So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and
then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their
forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly
and sadly:–
caption:
So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and
then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their
forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly
and sadly:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-601
text:
'"Will you walk a little faster?" said a whiting to a snail.
 "There's a porpoise close behind us, and he's treading on my tail.
caption:
'"Will you walk a little faster?" said a whiting to a snail.
 "There's a porpoise close behind us, and he's treading on my tail.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-602
text:
See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance!
 They are waiting on the shingle–will you come and join the dance?
caption:
See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance!
 They are waiting on the shingle–will you come and join the dance?

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-603
text:
Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, will you join the dance?
 Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, won't you join the dance?
caption:
Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, will you join the dance?
 Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, won't you join the dance?

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-604
text:
"You can really have no notion how delightful it will be
 When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!"
 But the snail replied "Too far, too far!" and gave a look askance–
 Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance.
caption:
"You can really have no notion how delightful it will be
 When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!"
 But the snail replied "Too far, too far!" and gave a look askance–
 Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-605
text:
Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance.
 Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance.
caption:
Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance.
 Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-606
text:
'"What matters it how far we go?" his scaly friend replied.
 "There is another shore, you know, upon the other side.
 The further off from England the nearer is to France–
 Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance.
caption:
'"What matters it how far we go?" his scaly friend replied.
 "There is another shore, you know, upon the other side.
 The further off from England the nearer is to France–
 Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-607
text:
Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, will you join the dance?
 Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, won't you join the dance?"'
caption:
Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, will you join the dance?
 Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, won't you join the dance?"'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-608
text:
'Thank you, it's a very interesting dance to watch,' said Alice, feeling
very glad that it was over at last: 'and I do so like that curious song
about the whiting!'
caption:
'Thank you, it's a very interesting dance to watch,' said Alice, feeling
very glad that it was over at last: 'and I do so like that curious song
about the whiting!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-609
text:
'Oh, as to the whiting,' said the Mock Turtle, 'they–you've seen them,
of course?'
caption:
'Oh, as to the whiting,' said the Mock Turtle, 'they–you've seen them,
of course?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-610
text:
'Yes,' said Alice, 'I've often seen them at dinn–' she checked herself
hastily.
caption:
'Yes,' said Alice, 'I've often seen them at dinn–' she checked herself
hastily.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-611
text:
'I don't know where Dinn may be,' said the Mock Turtle, 'but if you've
seen them so often, of course you know what they're like.'
caption:
'I don't know where Dinn may be,' said the Mock Turtle, 'but if you've
seen them so often, of course you know what they're like.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-612
text:
'I believe so,' Alice replied thoughtfully. 'They have their tails in
their mouths–and they're all over crumbs.'
caption:
'I believe so,' Alice replied thoughtfully. 'They have their tails in
their mouths–and they're all over crumbs.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-613
text:
'You're wrong about the crumbs,' said the Mock Turtle: 'crumbs would all
wash off in the sea. But they HAVE their tails in their mouths; and the
reason is–' here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.–'Tell her
about the reason and all that,' he said to the Gryphon.
caption:
'You're wrong about the crumbs,' said the Mock Turtle: 'crumbs would all
wash off in the sea. But they HAVE their tails in their mouths; and the
reason is–' here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.–'Tell her
about the reason and all that,' he said to the Gryphon.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-614
text:
'The reason is,' said the Gryphon, 'that they WOULD go with the lobsters
to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea. So they had to fall a long
way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they couldn't get
them out again. That's all.'
caption:
'The reason is,' said the Gryphon, 'that they WOULD go with the lobsters
to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea. So they had to fall a long
way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they couldn't get
them out again. That's all.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-615
text:
'Thank you,' said Alice, 'it's very interesting. I never knew so much
about a whiting before.'
caption:
'Thank you,' said Alice, 'it's very interesting. I never knew so much
about a whiting before.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-616
text:
'I can tell you more than that, if you like,' said the Gryphon. 'Do you
know why it's called a whiting?'
caption:
'I can tell you more than that, if you like,' said the Gryphon. 'Do you
know why it's called a whiting?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-617
text: 'I never thought about it,' said Alice. 'Why?'
caption: 'I never thought about it,' said Alice. 'Why?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-618
text: 'IT DOES THE BOOTS AND SHOES.' the Gryphon replied very solemnly.
caption: 'IT DOES THE BOOTS AND SHOES.' the Gryphon replied very solemnly.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-619
text:
Alice was thoroughly puzzled. 'Does the boots and shoes!' she repeated
in a wondering tone.
caption:
Alice was thoroughly puzzled. 'Does the boots and shoes!' she repeated
in a wondering tone.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-620
text:
'Why, what are YOUR shoes done with?' said the Gryphon. 'I mean, what
makes them so shiny?'
caption:
'Why, what are YOUR shoes done with?' said the Gryphon. 'I mean, what
makes them so shiny?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-621
text:
Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her
answer. 'They're done with blacking, I believe.'
caption:
Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her
answer. 'They're done with blacking, I believe.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-622
text:
'Boots and shoes under the sea,' the Gryphon went on in a deep voice,
'are done with a whiting. Now you know.'
caption:
'Boots and shoes under the sea,' the Gryphon went on in a deep voice,
'are done with a whiting. Now you know.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-623
text: 'And what are they made of?' Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.
caption: 'And what are they made of?' Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-624
text:
'Soles and eels, of course,' the Gryphon replied rather impatiently:
'any shrimp could have told you that.'
caption:
'Soles and eels, of course,' the Gryphon replied rather impatiently:
'any shrimp could have told you that.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-625
text:
'If I'd been the whiting,' said Alice, whose thoughts were still running
on the song, 'I'd have said to the porpoise, "Keep back, please: we
don't want YOU with us!"'
caption:
'If I'd been the whiting,' said Alice, whose thoughts were still running
on the song, 'I'd have said to the porpoise, "Keep back, please: we
don't want YOU with us!"'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-626
text:
'They were obliged to have him with them,' the Mock Turtle said: 'no
wise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise.'
caption:
'They were obliged to have him with them,' the Mock Turtle said: 'no
wise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-627
text: 'Wouldn't it really?' said Alice in a tone of great surprise.
caption: 'Wouldn't it really?' said Alice in a tone of great surprise.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-628
text:
'Of course not,' said the Mock Turtle: 'why, if a fish came to ME, and
told me he was going a journey, I should say "With what porpoise?"'
caption:
'Of course not,' said the Mock Turtle: 'why, if a fish came to ME, and
told me he was going a journey, I should say "With what porpoise?"'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-629
text: 'Don't you mean "purpose"?' said Alice.
caption: 'Don't you mean "purpose"?' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-630
text:
'I mean what I say,' the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And
the Gryphon added 'Come, let's hear some of YOUR adventures.'
caption:
'I mean what I say,' the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And
the Gryphon added 'Come, let's hear some of YOUR adventures.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-631
text:
'I could tell you my adventures–beginning from this morning,' said
Alice a little timidly: 'but it's no use going back to yesterday,
because I was a different person then.'
caption:
'I could tell you my adventures–beginning from this morning,' said
Alice a little timidly: 'but it's no use going back to yesterday,
because I was a different person then.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-632
text: 'Explain all that,' said the Mock Turtle.
caption: 'Explain all that,' said the Mock Turtle.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-633
text:
'No, no! The adventures first,' said the Gryphon in an impatient tone:
'explanations take such a dreadful time.'
caption:
'No, no! The adventures first,' said the Gryphon in an impatient tone:
'explanations take such a dreadful time.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-634
text:
So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first
saw the White Rabbit. She was a little nervous about it just at first,
the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened
their eyes and mouths so VERY wide, but she gained courage as she went
on. Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about
her repeating 'YOU ARE OLD, FATHER WILLIAM,' to the Caterpillar, and the
words all coming different, and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath,
and said 'That's very curious.'
caption:
So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first
saw the White Rabbit. She was a little nervous about it just at first,
the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened
their eyes and mouths so VERY wide, but she gained courage as she went
on. Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about
her repeating 'YOU ARE OLD, FATHER WILLIAM,' to the Caterpillar, and the
words all coming different, and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath,
and said 'That's very curious.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-635
text: 'It's all about as curious as it can be,' said the Gryphon.
caption: 'It's all about as curious as it can be,' said the Gryphon.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-636
text:
'It all came different!' the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully. 'I
should like to hear her try and repeat something now. Tell her to
begin.' He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of
authority over Alice.
caption:
'It all came different!' the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully. 'I
should like to hear her try and repeat something now. Tell her to
begin.' He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of
authority over Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-637
text:
'Stand up and repeat "'TIS THE VOICE OF THE SLUGGARD,"' said the
Gryphon.
caption:
'Stand up and repeat "'TIS THE VOICE OF THE SLUGGARD,"' said the
Gryphon.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-638
text:
'How the creatures order one about, and make one repeat lessons!'
thought Alice; 'I might as well be at school at once.' However, she
got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster
Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came
very queer indeed:–
caption:
'How the creatures order one about, and make one repeat lessons!'
thought Alice; 'I might as well be at school at once.' However, she
got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster
Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came
very queer indeed:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-639
text:
' 'Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare,
  "You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair."
  As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose
  Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes.'
caption:
' 'Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare,
  "You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair."
  As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose
  Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-640
text:
[later editions continued as follows
  When the sands are all dry, he is gay as a lark,
  And will talk in contemptuous tones of the Shark,
  But, when the tide rises and sharks are around,
  His voice has a timid and tremulous sound.]
caption:
[later editions continued as follows
  When the sands are all dry, he is gay as a lark,
  And will talk in contemptuous tones of the Shark,
  But, when the tide rises and sharks are around,
  His voice has a timid and tremulous sound.]

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-641
text:
'That's different from what I used to say when I was a child,' said the
Gryphon.
caption:
'That's different from what I used to say when I was a child,' said the
Gryphon.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-642
text:
'Well, I never heard it before,' said the Mock Turtle; 'but it sounds
uncommon nonsense.'
caption:
'Well, I never heard it before,' said the Mock Turtle; 'but it sounds
uncommon nonsense.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-643
text:
Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands,
wondering if anything would EVER happen in a natural way again.
caption:
Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands,
wondering if anything would EVER happen in a natural way again.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-644
text: 'I should like to have it explained,' said the Mock Turtle.
caption: 'I should like to have it explained,' said the Mock Turtle.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-645
text:
'She can't explain it,' said the Gryphon hastily. 'Go on with the next
verse.'
caption:
'She can't explain it,' said the Gryphon hastily. 'Go on with the next
verse.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-646
text:
'But about his toes?' the Mock Turtle persisted. 'How COULD he turn them
out with his nose, you know?'
caption:
'But about his toes?' the Mock Turtle persisted. 'How COULD he turn them
out with his nose, you know?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-647
text:
'It's the first position in dancing.' Alice said; but was dreadfully
puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.
caption:
'It's the first position in dancing.' Alice said; but was dreadfully
puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-648
text:
'Go on with the next verse,' the Gryphon repeated impatiently: 'it
begins "I passed by his garden."'
caption:
'Go on with the next verse,' the Gryphon repeated impatiently: 'it
begins "I passed by his garden."'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-649
text:
Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come
wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:–
caption:
Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come
wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-650
text:
'I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye,
  How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie–'
caption:
'I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye,
  How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-651
text:
[later editions continued as follows
  The Panther took pie-crust, and gravy, and meat,
  While the Owl had the dish as its share of the treat.
  When the pie was all finished, the Owl, as a boon,
  Was kindly permitted to pocket the spoon:
  While the Panther received knife and fork with a growl,
  And concluded the banquet–]
caption:
[later editions continued as follows
  The Panther took pie-crust, and gravy, and meat,
  While the Owl had the dish as its share of the treat.
  When the pie was all finished, the Owl, as a boon,
  Was kindly permitted to pocket the spoon:
  While the Panther received knife and fork with a growl,
  And concluded the banquet–]

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-652
text:
'What IS the use of repeating all that stuff,' the Mock Turtle
interrupted, 'if you don't explain it as you go on? It's by far the most
confusing thing I ever heard!'
caption:
'What IS the use of repeating all that stuff,' the Mock Turtle
interrupted, 'if you don't explain it as you go on? It's by far the most
confusing thing I ever heard!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-653
text:
'Yes, I think you'd better leave off,' said the Gryphon: and Alice was
only too glad to do so.
caption:
'Yes, I think you'd better leave off,' said the Gryphon: and Alice was
only too glad to do so.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-654
text:
'Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?' the Gryphon went
on. 'Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?'
caption:
'Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?' the Gryphon went
on. 'Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-655
text:
'Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,' Alice
replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone,
'Hm! No accounting for tastes! Sing her "Turtle Soup," will you, old
fellow?'
caption:
'Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,' Alice
replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone,
'Hm! No accounting for tastes! Sing her "Turtle Soup," will you, old
fellow?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-656
text:
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked
with sobs, to sing this:–
caption:
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked
with sobs, to sing this:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-657
text:
'Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
   Waiting in a hot tureen!
   Who for such dainties would not stoop?
   Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
   Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
     Beau–ootiful Soo–oop!
     Beau–ootiful Soo–oop!
   Soo–oop of the e–e–evening,
     Beautiful, beautiful Soup!
caption:
'Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
   Waiting in a hot tureen!
   Who for such dainties would not stoop?
   Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
   Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
     Beau–ootiful Soo–oop!
     Beau–ootiful Soo–oop!
   Soo–oop of the e–e–evening,
     Beautiful, beautiful Soup!

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-658
text:
'Beautiful Soup! Who cares for fish,
   Game, or any other dish?
   Who would not give all else for two
   Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
   Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
     Beau–ootiful Soo–oop!
     Beau–ootiful Soo–oop!
   Soo–oop of the e–e–evening,
     Beautiful, beauti–FUL SOUP!'
caption:
'Beautiful Soup! Who cares for fish,
   Game, or any other dish?
   Who would not give all else for two
   Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
   Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
     Beau–ootiful Soo–oop!
     Beau–ootiful Soo–oop!
   Soo–oop of the e–e–evening,
     Beautiful, beauti–FUL SOUP!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-659
text:
'Chorus again!' cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun
to repeat it, when a cry of 'The trial's beginning!' was heard in the
distance.
caption:
'Chorus again!' cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun
to repeat it, when a cry of 'The trial's beginning!' was heard in the
distance.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-660
text:
'Come on!' cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried
off, without waiting for the end of the song.
caption:
'Come on!' cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried
off, without waiting for the end of the song.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-661
text:
'What trial is it?' Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only
answered 'Come on!' and ran the faster, while more and more faintly
came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:–
caption:
'What trial is it?' Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only
answered 'Come on!' and ran the faster, while more and more faintly
came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-662
text:
'Soo–oop of the e–e–evening,
     Beautiful, beautiful Soup!'
caption:
'Soo–oop of the e–e–evening,
     Beautiful, beautiful Soup!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-663
text: CHAPTER XI. Who Stole the Tarts?
caption: CHAPTER XI. Who Stole the Tarts?

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-664
text:
The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they
arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them–all sorts of little
birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was
standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard
him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand,
and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the court
was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good,
that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them–'I wish they'd get the
trial done,' she thought, 'and hand round the refreshments!' But there
seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about
her, to pass away the time.
caption:
The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they
arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them–all sorts of little
birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was
standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard
him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand,
and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the court
was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good,
that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them–'I wish they'd get the
trial done,' she thought, 'and hand round the refreshments!' But there
seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about
her, to pass away the time.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-665
text:
Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read
about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew
the name of nearly everything there. 'That's the judge,' she said to
herself, 'because of his great wig.'
caption:
Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read
about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew
the name of nearly everything there. 'That's the judge,' she said to
herself, 'because of his great wig.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-666
text:
The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the
wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did
not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.
caption:
The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the
wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did
not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-667
text:
'And that's the jury-box,' thought Alice, 'and those twelve creatures,'
(she was obliged to say 'creatures,' you see, because some of them were
animals, and some were birds,) 'I suppose they are the jurors.' She said
this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of
it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her
age knew the meaning of it at all. However, 'jury-men' would have done
just as well.
caption:
'And that's the jury-box,' thought Alice, 'and those twelve creatures,'
(she was obliged to say 'creatures,' you see, because some of them were
animals, and some were birds,) 'I suppose they are the jurors.' She said
this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of
it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her
age knew the meaning of it at all. However, 'jury-men' would have done
just as well.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-668
text:
The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. 'What are they
doing?' Alice whispered to the Gryphon. 'They can't have anything to put
down yet, before the trial's begun.'
caption:
The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. 'What are they
doing?' Alice whispered to the Gryphon. 'They can't have anything to put
down yet, before the trial's begun.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-669
text:
'They're putting down their names,' the Gryphon whispered in reply, 'for
fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.'
caption:
'They're putting down their names,' the Gryphon whispered in reply, 'for
fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-670
text:
'Stupid things!' Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped
hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, 'Silence in the court!' and the
King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who
was talking.
caption:
'Stupid things!' Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped
hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, 'Silence in the court!' and the
King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who
was talking.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-671
text:
Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders,
that all the jurors were writing down 'stupid things!' on their slates,
and she could even make out that one of them didn't know how to spell
'stupid,' and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him. 'A nice
muddle their slates'll be in before the trial's over!' thought Alice.
caption:
Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders,
that all the jurors were writing down 'stupid things!' on their slates,
and she could even make out that one of them didn't know how to spell
'stupid,' and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him. 'A nice
muddle their slates'll be in before the trial's over!' thought Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-672
text:
One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, Alice
could not stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and
very soon found an opportunity of taking it away. She did it so quickly
that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out
at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was
obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was
of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.
caption:
One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, Alice
could not stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and
very soon found an opportunity of taking it away. She did it so quickly
that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out
at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was
obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was
of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-673
text: 'Herald, read the accusation!' said the King.
caption: 'Herald, read the accusation!' said the King.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-674
text:
On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then
unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:–
caption:
On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then
unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-675
text:
'The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,
      All on a summer day:
    The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,
      And took them quite away!'
caption:
'The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,
      All on a summer day:
    The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,
      And took them quite away!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-676
text: 'Consider your verdict,' the King said to the jury.
caption: 'Consider your verdict,' the King said to the jury.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-677
text:
'Not yet, not yet!' the Rabbit hastily interrupted. 'There's a great
deal to come before that!'
caption:
'Not yet, not yet!' the Rabbit hastily interrupted. 'There's a great
deal to come before that!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-678
text:
'Call the first witness,' said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three
blasts on the trumpet, and called out, 'First witness!'
caption:
'Call the first witness,' said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three
blasts on the trumpet, and called out, 'First witness!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-679
text:
The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one
hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. 'I beg pardon, your
Majesty,' he began, 'for bringing these in: but I hadn't quite finished
my tea when I was sent for.'
caption:
The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one
hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. 'I beg pardon, your
Majesty,' he began, 'for bringing these in: but I hadn't quite finished
my tea when I was sent for.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-680
text: 'You ought to have finished,' said the King. 'When did you begin?'
caption: 'You ought to have finished,' said the King. 'When did you begin?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-681
text:
The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the
court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse. 'Fourteenth of March, I think it
was,' he said.
caption:
The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the
court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse. 'Fourteenth of March, I think it
was,' he said.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-682
text: 'Fifteenth,' said the March Hare.
caption: 'Fifteenth,' said the March Hare.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-683
text: 'Sixteenth,' added the Dormouse.
caption: 'Sixteenth,' added the Dormouse.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-684
text:
'Write that down,' the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly
wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and
reduced the answer to shillings and pence.
caption:
'Write that down,' the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly
wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and
reduced the answer to shillings and pence.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-685
text: 'Take off your hat,' the King said to the Hatter.
caption: 'Take off your hat,' the King said to the Hatter.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-686
text: 'It isn't mine,' said the Hatter.
caption: 'It isn't mine,' said the Hatter.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-687
text:
'Stolen!' the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a
memorandum of the fact.
caption:
'Stolen!' the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a
memorandum of the fact.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-688
text:
'I keep them to sell,' the Hatter added as an explanation; 'I've none of
my own. I'm a hatter.'
caption:
'I keep them to sell,' the Hatter added as an explanation; 'I've none of
my own. I'm a hatter.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-689
text:
Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter,
who turned pale and fidgeted.
caption:
Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter,
who turned pale and fidgeted.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-690
text:
'Give your evidence,' said the King; 'and don't be nervous, or I'll have
you executed on the spot.'
caption:
'Give your evidence,' said the King; 'and don't be nervous, or I'll have
you executed on the spot.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-691
text:
This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting
from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in
his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the
bread-and-butter.
caption:
This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting
from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in
his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the
bread-and-butter.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-692
text:
Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled
her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to
grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave
the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as
long as there was room for her.
caption:
Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled
her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to
grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave
the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as
long as there was room for her.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-693
text:
'I wish you wouldn't squeeze so.' said the Dormouse, who was sitting
next to her. 'I can hardly breathe.'
caption:
'I wish you wouldn't squeeze so.' said the Dormouse, who was sitting
next to her. 'I can hardly breathe.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-694
text: 'I can't help it,' said Alice very meekly: 'I'm growing.'
caption: 'I can't help it,' said Alice very meekly: 'I'm growing.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-695
text: 'You've no right to grow here,' said the Dormouse.
caption: 'You've no right to grow here,' said the Dormouse.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-696
text:
'Don't talk nonsense,' said Alice more boldly: 'you know you're growing
too.'
caption:
'Don't talk nonsense,' said Alice more boldly: 'you know you're growing
too.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-697
text:
'Yes, but I grow at a reasonable pace,' said the Dormouse: 'not in that
ridiculous fashion.' And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the
other side of the court.
caption:
'Yes, but I grow at a reasonable pace,' said the Dormouse: 'not in that
ridiculous fashion.' And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the
other side of the court.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-698
text:
All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and,
just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers
of the court, 'Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!' on
which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.
caption:
All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and,
just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers
of the court, 'Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!' on
which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-699
text:
'Give your evidence,' the King repeated angrily, 'or I'll have you
executed, whether you're nervous or not.'
caption:
'Give your evidence,' the King repeated angrily, 'or I'll have you
executed, whether you're nervous or not.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-700
text:
'I'm a poor man, your Majesty,' the Hatter began, in a trembling voice,
'–and I hadn't begun my tea–not above a week or so–and what with the
bread-and-butter getting so thin–and the twinkling of the tea–'
caption:
'I'm a poor man, your Majesty,' the Hatter began, in a trembling voice,
'–and I hadn't begun my tea–not above a week or so–and what with the
bread-and-butter getting so thin–and the twinkling of the tea–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-701
text: 'The twinkling of the what?' said the King.
caption: 'The twinkling of the what?' said the King.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-702
text: 'It began with the tea,' the Hatter replied.
caption: 'It began with the tea,' the Hatter replied.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-703
text:
'Of course twinkling begins with a T!' said the King sharply. 'Do you
take me for a dunce? Go on!'
caption:
'Of course twinkling begins with a T!' said the King sharply. 'Do you
take me for a dunce? Go on!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-704
text:
'I'm a poor man,' the Hatter went on, 'and most things twinkled after
that–only the March Hare said–'
caption:
'I'm a poor man,' the Hatter went on, 'and most things twinkled after
that–only the March Hare said–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-705
text: 'I didn't!' the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.
caption: 'I didn't!' the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-706
text: 'You did!' said the Hatter.
caption: 'You did!' said the Hatter.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-707
text: 'I deny it!' said the March Hare.
caption: 'I deny it!' said the March Hare.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-708
text: 'He denies it,' said the King: 'leave out that part.'
caption: 'He denies it,' said the King: 'leave out that part.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-709
text:
'Well, at any rate, the Dormouse said–' the Hatter went on, looking
anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied
nothing, being fast asleep.
caption:
'Well, at any rate, the Dormouse said–' the Hatter went on, looking
anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied
nothing, being fast asleep.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-710
text: 'After that,' continued the Hatter, 'I cut some more bread-and-butter–'
caption: 'After that,' continued the Hatter, 'I cut some more bread-and-butter–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-711
text: 'But what did the Dormouse say?' one of the jury asked.
caption: 'But what did the Dormouse say?' one of the jury asked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-712
text: 'That I can't remember,' said the Hatter.
caption: 'That I can't remember,' said the Hatter.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-713
text: 'You MUST remember,' remarked the King, 'or I'll have you executed.'
caption: 'You MUST remember,' remarked the King, 'or I'll have you executed.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-714
text:
The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went
down on one knee. 'I'm a poor man, your Majesty,' he began.
caption:
The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went
down on one knee. 'I'm a poor man, your Majesty,' he began.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-715
text: 'You're a very poor speaker,' said the King.
caption: 'You're a very poor speaker,' said the King.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-716
text:
Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by
the officers of the court. (As that is rather a hard word, I will just
explain to you how it was done. They had a large canvas bag, which tied
up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig,
head first, and then sat upon it.)
caption:
Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by
the officers of the court. (As that is rather a hard word, I will just
explain to you how it was done. They had a large canvas bag, which tied
up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig,
head first, and then sat upon it.)

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-717
text:
'I'm glad I've seen that done,' thought Alice. 'I've so often read
in the newspapers, at the end of trials, "There was some attempts
at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the
court," and I never understood what it meant till now.'
caption:
'I'm glad I've seen that done,' thought Alice. 'I've so often read
in the newspapers, at the end of trials, "There was some attempts
at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the
court," and I never understood what it meant till now.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-718
text:
'If that's all you know about it, you may stand down,' continued the
King.
caption:
'If that's all you know about it, you may stand down,' continued the
King.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-719
text: 'I can't go no lower,' said the Hatter: 'I'm on the floor, as it is.'
caption: 'I can't go no lower,' said the Hatter: 'I'm on the floor, as it is.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-720
text: 'Then you may SIT down,' the King replied.
caption: 'Then you may SIT down,' the King replied.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-721
text: Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.
caption: Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-722
text:
'Come, that finished the guinea-pigs!' thought Alice. 'Now we shall get
on better.'
caption:
'Come, that finished the guinea-pigs!' thought Alice. 'Now we shall get
on better.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-723
text:
'I'd rather finish my tea,' said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the
Queen, who was reading the list of singers.
caption:
'I'd rather finish my tea,' said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the
Queen, who was reading the list of singers.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-724
text:
'You may go,' said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court,
without even waiting to put his shoes on.
caption:
'You may go,' said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court,
without even waiting to put his shoes on.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-725
text:
'–and just take his head off outside,' the Queen added to one of the
officers: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get
to the door.
caption:
'–and just take his head off outside,' the Queen added to one of the
officers: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get
to the door.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-726
text: 'Call the next witness!' said the King.
caption: 'Call the next witness!' said the King.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-727
text:
The next witness was the Duchess's cook. She carried the pepper-box in
her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the
court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.
caption:
The next witness was the Duchess's cook. She carried the pepper-box in
her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the
court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-728
text: 'Give your evidence,' said the King.
caption: 'Give your evidence,' said the King.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-729
text: 'Shan't,' said the cook.
caption: 'Shan't,' said the cook.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-730
text:
The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who said in a low voice,
'Your Majesty must cross-examine THIS witness.'
caption:
The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who said in a low voice,
'Your Majesty must cross-examine THIS witness.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-731
text:
'Well, if I must, I must,' the King said, with a melancholy air, and,
after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were
nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, 'What are tarts made of?'
caption:
'Well, if I must, I must,' the King said, with a melancholy air, and,
after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were
nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, 'What are tarts made of?'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-732
text: 'Pepper, mostly,' said the cook.
caption: 'Pepper, mostly,' said the cook.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-733
text: 'Treacle,' said a sleepy voice behind her.
caption: 'Treacle,' said a sleepy voice behind her.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-734
text:
'Collar that Dormouse,' the Queen shrieked out. 'Behead that Dormouse!
Turn that Dormouse out of court! Suppress him! Pinch him! Off with his
whiskers!'
caption:
'Collar that Dormouse,' the Queen shrieked out. 'Behead that Dormouse!
Turn that Dormouse out of court! Suppress him! Pinch him! Off with his
whiskers!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-735
text:
For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse
turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had
disappeared.
caption:
For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse
turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had
disappeared.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-736
text:
'Never mind!' said the King, with an air of great relief. 'Call the next
witness.' And he added in an undertone to the Queen, 'Really, my dear,
YOU must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead
ache!'
caption:
'Never mind!' said the King, with an air of great relief. 'Call the next
witness.' And he added in an undertone to the Queen, 'Really, my dear,
YOU must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead
ache!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-737
text:
Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list, feeling very
curious to see what the next witness would be like, '–for they haven't
got much evidence YET,' she said to herself. Imagine her surprise, when
the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the
name 'Alice!'
caption:
Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list, feeling very
curious to see what the next witness would be like, '–for they haven't
got much evidence YET,' she said to herself. Imagine her surprise, when
the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the
name 'Alice!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-738
text: CHAPTER XII. Alice's Evidence
caption: CHAPTER XII. Alice's Evidence

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-739
text:
'Here!' cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how
large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such
a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt,
upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there
they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish
she had accidentally upset the week before.
caption:
'Here!' cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how
large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such
a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt,
upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there
they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish
she had accidentally upset the week before.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-740
text:
'Oh, I BEG your pardon!' she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and
began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of
the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea
that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or
they would die.
caption:
'Oh, I BEG your pardon!' she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and
began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of
the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea
that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or
they would die.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-741
text:
'The trial cannot proceed,' said the King in a very grave voice, 'until
all the jurymen are back in their proper places–ALL,' he repeated with
great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said do.
caption:
'The trial cannot proceed,' said the King in a very grave voice, 'until
all the jurymen are back in their proper places–ALL,' he repeated with
great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said do.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-742
text:
Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put
the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its
tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move. She soon got
it out again, and put it right; 'not that it signifies much,' she said
to herself; 'I should think it would be QUITE as much use in the trial
one way up as the other.'
caption:
Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put
the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its
tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move. She soon got
it out again, and put it right; 'not that it signifies much,' she said
to herself; 'I should think it would be QUITE as much use in the trial
one way up as the other.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-743
text:
As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being
upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to
them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the
accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do
anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the
court.
caption:
As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being
upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to
them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the
accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do
anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the
court.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-744
text: 'What do you know about this business?' the King said to Alice.
caption: 'What do you know about this business?' the King said to Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-745
text: 'Nothing,' said Alice.
caption: 'Nothing,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-746
text: 'Nothing WHATEVER?' persisted the King.
caption: 'Nothing WHATEVER?' persisted the King.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-747
text: 'Nothing whatever,' said Alice.
caption: 'Nothing whatever,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-748
text:
'That's very important,' the King said, turning to the jury. They were
just beginning to write this down on their slates, when the White Rabbit
interrupted: 'UNimportant, your Majesty means, of course,' he said in a
very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.
caption:
'That's very important,' the King said, turning to the jury. They were
just beginning to write this down on their slates, when the White Rabbit
interrupted: 'UNimportant, your Majesty means, of course,' he said in a
very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-749
text:
'UNimportant, of course, I meant,' the King hastily said, and went on
to himself in an undertone,
caption:
'UNimportant, of course, I meant,' the King hastily said, and went on
to himself in an undertone,

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-750
text:
'important–unimportant–unimportant–important–' as if he were trying
which word sounded best.
caption:
'important–unimportant–unimportant–important–' as if he were trying
which word sounded best.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-751
Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-752
text:
At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in
his note-book, cackled out 'Silence!' and read out from his book, 'Rule
Forty-two. ALL PERSONS MORE THAN A MILE HIGH TO LEAVE THE COURT.'
caption:
At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in
his note-book, cackled out 'Silence!' and read out from his book, 'Rule
Forty-two. ALL PERSONS MORE THAN A MILE HIGH TO LEAVE THE COURT.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-753
text: Everybody looked at Alice.
caption: Everybody looked at Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-754
text: 'I'M not a mile high,' said Alice.
caption: 'I'M not a mile high,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-755
text: 'You are,' said the King.
caption: 'You are,' said the King.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-756
text: 'Nearly two miles high,' added the Queen.
caption: 'Nearly two miles high,' added the Queen.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-757
text:
'Well, I shan't go, at any rate,' said Alice: 'besides, that's not a
regular rule: you invented it just now.'
caption:
'Well, I shan't go, at any rate,' said Alice: 'besides, that's not a
regular rule: you invented it just now.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-758
text: 'It's the oldest rule in the book,' said the King.
caption: 'It's the oldest rule in the book,' said the King.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-759
text: 'Then it ought to be Number One,' said Alice.
caption: 'Then it ought to be Number One,' said Alice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-760
text:
The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily. 'Consider your
verdict,' he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.
caption:
The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily. 'Consider your
verdict,' he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-761
text:
'There's more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,' said the White
Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; 'this paper has just been picked
up.'
caption:
'There's more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,' said the White
Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; 'this paper has just been picked
up.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-762
text: 'What's in it?' said the Queen.
caption: 'What's in it?' said the Queen.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-763
text:
'I haven't opened it yet,' said the White Rabbit, 'but it seems to be a
letter, written by the prisoner to–to somebody.'
caption:
'I haven't opened it yet,' said the White Rabbit, 'but it seems to be a
letter, written by the prisoner to–to somebody.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-764
text:
'It must have been that,' said the King, 'unless it was written to
nobody, which isn't usual, you know.'
caption:
'It must have been that,' said the King, 'unless it was written to
nobody, which isn't usual, you know.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-765
text: 'Who is it directed to?' said one of the jurymen.
caption: 'Who is it directed to?' said one of the jurymen.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-766
text:
'It isn't directed at all,' said the White Rabbit; 'in fact, there's
nothing written on the OUTSIDE.' He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and
added 'It isn't a letter, after all: it's a set of verses.'
caption:
'It isn't directed at all,' said the White Rabbit; 'in fact, there's
nothing written on the OUTSIDE.' He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and
added 'It isn't a letter, after all: it's a set of verses.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-767
text: 'Are they in the prisoner's handwriting?' asked another of the jurymen.
caption: 'Are they in the prisoner's handwriting?' asked another of the jurymen.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-768
text:
'No, they're not,' said the White Rabbit, 'and that's the queerest thing
about it.' (The jury all looked puzzled.)
caption:
'No, they're not,' said the White Rabbit, 'and that's the queerest thing
about it.' (The jury all looked puzzled.)

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-769
text:
'He must have imitated somebody else's hand,' said the King. (The jury
all brightened up again.)
caption:
'He must have imitated somebody else's hand,' said the King. (The jury
all brightened up again.)

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-770
text:
'Please your Majesty,' said the Knave, 'I didn't write it, and they
can't prove I did: there's no name signed at the end.'
caption:
'Please your Majesty,' said the Knave, 'I didn't write it, and they
can't prove I did: there's no name signed at the end.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-771
text:
'If you didn't sign it,' said the King, 'that only makes the matter
worse. You MUST have meant some mischief, or else you'd have signed your
name like an honest man.'
caption:
'If you didn't sign it,' said the King, 'that only makes the matter
worse. You MUST have meant some mischief, or else you'd have signed your
name like an honest man.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-772
text:
There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really
clever thing the King had said that day.
caption:
There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really
clever thing the King had said that day.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-773
text: 'That PROVES his guilt,' said the Queen.
caption: 'That PROVES his guilt,' said the Queen.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-774
text:
'It proves nothing of the sort!' said Alice. 'Why, you don't even know
what they're about!'
caption:
'It proves nothing of the sort!' said Alice. 'Why, you don't even know
what they're about!'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-775
text: 'Read them,' said the King.
caption: 'Read them,' said the King.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-776
text:
The White Rabbit put on his spectacles. 'Where shall I begin, please
your Majesty?' he asked.
caption:
The White Rabbit put on his spectacles. 'Where shall I begin, please
your Majesty?' he asked.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-777
text:
'Begin at the beginning,' the King said gravely, 'and go on till you
come to the end: then stop.'
caption:
'Begin at the beginning,' the King said gravely, 'and go on till you
come to the end: then stop.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-778
text: These were the verses the White Rabbit read:–
caption: These were the verses the White Rabbit read:–

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-779
text:
'They told me you had been to her,
    And mentioned me to him:
   She gave me a good character,
    But said I could not swim.
caption:
'They told me you had been to her,
    And mentioned me to him:
   She gave me a good character,
    But said I could not swim.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-780
text:
He sent them word I had not gone
    (We know it to be true):
   If she should push the matter on,
    What would become of you?
caption:
He sent them word I had not gone
    (We know it to be true):
   If she should push the matter on,
    What would become of you?

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-781
text:
I gave her one, they gave him two,
    You gave us three or more;
   They all returned from him to you,
    Though they were mine before.
caption:
I gave her one, they gave him two,
    You gave us three or more;
   They all returned from him to you,
    Though they were mine before.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-782
text:
If I or she should chance to be
    Involved in this affair,
   He trusts to you to set them free,
    Exactly as we were.
caption:
If I or she should chance to be
    Involved in this affair,
   He trusts to you to set them free,
    Exactly as we were.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-783
text:
My notion was that you had been
    (Before she had this fit)
   An obstacle that came between
    Him, and ourselves, and it.
caption:
My notion was that you had been
    (Before she had this fit)
   An obstacle that came between
    Him, and ourselves, and it.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-784
text:
Don't let him know she liked them best,
    For this must ever be
   A secret, kept from all the rest,
    Between yourself and me.'
caption:
Don't let him know she liked them best,
    For this must ever be
   A secret, kept from all the rest,
    Between yourself and me.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-785
text:
'That's the most important piece of evidence we've heard yet,' said the
King, rubbing his hands; 'so now let the jury–'
caption:
'That's the most important piece of evidence we've heard yet,' said the
King, rubbing his hands; 'so now let the jury–'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-786
text:
'If any one of them can explain it,' said Alice, (she had grown so large
in the last few minutes that she wasn't a bit afraid of interrupting
him,) 'I'll give him sixpence. _I_ don't believe there's an atom of
meaning in it.'
caption:
'If any one of them can explain it,' said Alice, (she had grown so large
in the last few minutes that she wasn't a bit afraid of interrupting
him,) 'I'll give him sixpence. _I_ don't believe there's an atom of
meaning in it.'

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-787
text:
The jury all wrote down on their slates, 'SHE doesn't believe there's an
atom of meaning in it,' but none of them attempted to explain the paper.
caption:
The jury all wrote down on their slates, 'SHE doesn't believe there's an
atom of meaning in it,' but none of them attempted to explain the paper.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-788
text:
'If there's no meaning in it,' said the King, 'that saves a world of
trouble, you know, as we needn't try to find any. And yet I don't know,'
he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them
with one eye; 'I seem to see some meaning in them, after all. "–SAID
I COULD NOT SWIM–" you can't swim, can you?' he added, turning to the
Knave.
caption:
'If there's no meaning in it,' said the King, 'that saves a world of
trouble, you know, as we needn't try to find any. And yet I don't know,'
he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them
with one eye; 'I seem to see some meaning in them, after all. "–SAID
I COULD NOT SWIM–" you can't swim, can you?' he added, turning to the
Knave.

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-789
text:
The Knave shook his head sadly. 'Do I look like it?' he said. (Which he
certainly did NOT, being made entirely of cardboard.)
caption:
The Knave shook his head sadly. 'Do I look like it?' he said. (Which he
certainly did NOT, being made entirely of cardboard.)

title: Alice in Wonderland:-paragraph-790
text:
'All right, so far,' said the King, and he went on muttering over
the verses to himself: '"WE KNOW IT TO BE TRUE–" that's the jury, of
